2577 @doc(storage_options=generic._shared_docs["storage_options"])
2578 @deprecate_kwarg(old_arg_name="fname", new_arg_name="path")
2579 def to_parquet(
2580 self,
2581 path: FilePathOrBuffer | None = None,
2582 engine: str = "auto",
2583 compression: str | None = "snappy",
2584 index: bool | None = None,
2585 partition_cols: list[str] | None = None,
2586 storage_options: StorageOptions = None,
2587 **kwargs,
2588 ) -> bytes | None:
2589 """
2590 Write a DataFrame to the binary parquet format.
2591  
2592 This function writes the dataframe as a `parquet file
2593 <https://parquet.apache.org/>`_. You can choose different parquet
2594 backends, and have the option of compression. See
2595 :ref:`the user guide <io.parquet>` for more details.
2596  
2597 Parameters
2598 ----------
2599 path : str or file-like object, default None
2600 If a string, it will be used as Root Directory path
2601 when writing a partitioned dataset. By file-like object,
2602 we refer to objects with a write() method, such as a file handle
2603 (e.g. via builtin open function) or io.BytesIO. The engine
2604 fastparquet does not accept file-like objects. If path is None,
2605 a bytes object is returned.
2606  
2607 .. versionchanged:: 1.2.0
2608  
2609 Previously this was "fname"
2610  
2611 engine : {{'auto', 'pyarrow', 'fastparquet'}}, default 'auto'
2612 Parquet library to use. If 'auto', then the option
2613 ``io.parquet.engine`` is used. The default ``io.parquet.engine``
2614 behavior is to try 'pyarrow', falling back to 'fastparquet' if
2615 'pyarrow' is unavailable.
2616 compression : {{'snappy', 'gzip', 'brotli', None}}, default 'snappy'
2617 Name of the compression to use. Use ``None`` for no compression.
2618 index : bool, default None
2619 If ``True``, include the dataframe's index(es) in the file output.
2620 If ``False``, they will not be written to the file.
2621 If ``None``, similar to ``True`` the dataframe's index(es)
2622 will be saved. However, instead of being saved as values,
2623 the RangeIndex will be stored as a range in the metadata so it
2624 doesn't require much space and is faster. Other indexes will
2625 be included as columns in the file output.
2626 partition_cols : list, optional, default None
2627 Column names by which to partition the dataset.
2628 Columns are partitioned in the order they are given.
2629 Must be None if path is not a string.
2630 {storage_options}
2631  
2632 .. versionadded:: 1.2.0
2633  
2634 **kwargs
2635 Additional arguments passed to the parquet library. See
2636 :ref:`pandas io <io.parquet>` for more details.
2637  
2638 Returns
2639 -------
2640 bytes if no path argument is provided else None
2641  
2642 See Also
2643 --------
2644 read_parquet : Read a parquet file.
2645 DataFrame.to_csv : Write a csv file.
2646 DataFrame.to_sql : Write to a sql table.
2647 DataFrame.to_hdf : Write to hdf.
2648  
2649 Notes
2650 -----
2651 This function requires either the `fastparquet
2652 <https://pypi.org/project/fastparquet>`_ or `pyarrow
2653 <https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/>`_ library.
2654  
2655 Examples
2656 --------
2657 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data={{'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]}})
2658 >>> df.to_parquet('df.parquet.gzip',
2659 ... compression='gzip') # doctest: +SKIP
2660 >>> pd.read_parquet('df.parquet.gzip') # doctest: +SKIP
2661 col1 col2
2662 0 1 3
2663 1 2 4
2664  
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
2665 If you want to get a buffer to the parquet content you can use a io.BytesIO
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
2666 object, as long as you don't use partition_cols, which creates multiple files.
2667  
2668 >>> import io
2669 >>> f = io.BytesIO()
2670 >>> df.to_parquet(f)
2671 >>> f.seek(0)
2672 0
2673 >>> content = f.read()
2674 """
2675 from pandas.io.parquet import to_parquet
2676  
2677 return to_parquet(
2678 self,
2679 path,
2680 engine,
2681 compression=compression,
2682 index=index,
2683 partition_cols=partition_cols,
2684 storage_options=storage_options,
2685 **kwargs,
2686 )
2687  
2688 @Substitution(
2689 header_type="bool",
2690 header="Whether to print column labels, default True",
2691 col_space_type="str or int, list or dict of int or str",
2692 col_space="The minimum width of each column in CSS length "
2693 "units. An int is assumed to be px units.\n\n"
2694 " .. versionadded:: 0.25.0\n"
2695 " Ability to use str",
2696 )
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
2697 @Substitution(shared_params=fmt.common_docstring, returns=fmt.return_docstring)
2698 def to_html(
2699 self,
2700 buf: FilePathOrBuffer[str] | None = None,
2701 columns: Sequence[str] | None = None,
2702 col_space: ColspaceArgType | None = None,
2703 header: bool | Sequence[str] = True,

2706 formatters: FormattersType | None = None,

2708 sparsify: bool | None = None,

2712 max_cols: int | None = None,

2714 decimal: str = ".",

2723 ):
2724 """
2725 Render a DataFrame as an HTML table.
2726 %(shared_params)s
2727 bold_rows : bool, default True
2728 Make the row labels bold in the output.
2729 classes : str or list or tuple, default None
2730 CSS class(es) to apply to the resulting html table.
2731 escape : bool, default True
2732 Convert the characters <, >, and & to HTML-safe sequences.
2733 notebook : {True, False}, default False
2734 Whether the generated HTML is for IPython Notebook.
2735 border : int
2736 A ``border=border`` attribute is included in the opening
2737 `<table>` tag. Default ``pd.options.display.html.border``.
2738 encoding : str, default "utf-8"
2739 Set character encoding.
2740  
2741 .. versionadded:: 1.0
2742  
2743 table_id : str, optional
2744 A css id is included in the opening `<table>` tag if specified.
2745 render_links : bool, default False
2746 Convert URLs to HTML links.
2747 %(returns)s
2748 See Also
2749 --------
2750 to_string : Convert DataFrame to a string.
2751 """
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
2752 if justify is not None and justify not in fmt._VALID_JUSTIFY_PARAMETERS:
2753 raise ValueError("Invalid value for justify parameter")
2754  
2755 formatter = fmt.DataFrameFormatter(
2756 self,
2757 columns=columns,
2758 col_space=col_space,
2759 na_rep=na_rep,
2760 header=header,
2761 index=index,
2762 formatters=formatters,
2763 float_format=float_format,
2764 bold_rows=bold_rows,
2765 sparsify=sparsify,
2766 justify=justify,
2767 index_names=index_names,
2768 escape=escape,

2770 max_rows=max_rows,
2771 max_cols=max_cols,
2772 show_dimensions=show_dimensions,
2773 )
2774 # TODO: a generic formatter wld b in DataFrameFormatter
2775 return fmt.DataFrameRenderer(formatter).to_html(
2776 buf=buf,
2777 classes=classes,
2778 notebook=notebook,
2779 border=border,
2780 encoding=encoding,
2781 table_id=table_id,
2782 render_links=render_links,
2783 )

2785 @doc(storage_options=generic._shared_docs["storage_options"])
2786 def to_xml(
2787 self,
2788 path_or_buffer: FilePathOrBuffer | None = None,
2789 index: bool = True,
2790 root_name: str | None = "data",
2791 row_name: str | None = "row",
2792 na_rep: str | None = None,
2793 attr_cols: str | list[str] | None = None,
2794 elem_cols: str | list[str] | None = None,
2795 namespaces: dict[str | None, str] | None = None,
2796 prefix: str | None = None,
2797 encoding: str = "utf-8",
2798 xml_declaration: bool | None = True,
2799 pretty_print: bool | None = True,
2800 parser: str | None = "lxml",
2801 stylesheet: FilePathOrBuffer | None = None,
2802 compression: CompressionOptions = "infer",
2803 storage_options: StorageOptions = None,
2804 ) -> str | None:
2805 """
2806 Render a DataFrame to an XML document.
2807  
2808 .. versionadded:: 1.3.0
2809  
2810 Parameters
2811 ----------
2812 path_or_buffer : str, path object or file-like object, optional
2813 File to write output to. If None, the output is returned as a
2814 string.
2815 index : bool, default True
2816 Whether to include index in XML document.
2817 root_name : str, default 'data'
2818 The name of root element in XML document.
2819 row_name : str, default 'row'
2820 The name of row element in XML document.
2821 na_rep : str, optional
2822 Missing data representation.
2823 attr_cols : list-like, optional
2824 List of columns to write as attributes in row element.
2825 Hierarchical columns will be flattened with underscore
2826 delimiting the different levels.
2827 elem_cols : list-like, optional
2828 List of columns to write as children in row element. By default,
2829 all columns output as children of row element. Hierarchical
2830 columns will be flattened with underscore delimiting the
2831 different levels.
2832 namespaces : dict, optional
2833 All namespaces to be defined in root element. Keys of dict
2834 should be prefix names and values of dict corresponding URIs.
2835 Default namespaces should be given empty string key. For
2836 example, ::
2837  
2838 namespaces = {{"": "https://example.com"}}
2839  
2840 prefix : str, optional
2841 Namespace prefix to be used for every element and/or attribute
2842 in document. This should be one of the keys in ``namespaces``
2843 dict.
2844 encoding : str, default 'utf-8'
2845 Encoding of the resulting document.
2846 xml_declaration : bool, default True
2847 Whether to include the XML declaration at start of document.
2848 pretty_print : bool, default True
2849 Whether output should be pretty printed with indentation and
2850 line breaks.
2851 parser : {{'lxml','etree'}}, default 'lxml'
2852 Parser module to use for building of tree. Only 'lxml' and
2853 'etree' are supported. With 'lxml', the ability to use XSLT
2854 stylesheet is supported.
2855 stylesheet : str, path object or file-like object, optional
2856 A URL, file-like object, or a raw string containing an XSLT
2857 script used to transform the raw XML output. Script should use
2858 layout of elements and attributes from original output. This
2859 argument requires ``lxml`` to be installed. Only XSLT 1.0
2860 scripts and not later versions is currently supported.
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
2861 compression : {{'infer', 'gzip', 'bz2', 'zip', 'xz', None}}, default 'infer'
2862 For on-the-fly decompression of on-disk data. If 'infer', then use
2863 gzip, bz2, zip or xz if path_or_buffer is a string ending in
2864 '.gz', '.bz2', '.zip', or 'xz', respectively, and no decompression
2865 otherwise. If using 'zip', the ZIP file must contain only one data
2866 file to be read in. Set to None for no decompression.
2867 {storage_options}
2868  
2869 Returns
2870 -------
2871 None or str
2872 If ``io`` is None, returns the resulting XML format as a
2873 string. Otherwise returns None.
2874  
2875 See Also
2876 --------
2877 to_json : Convert the pandas object to a JSON string.
2878 to_html : Convert DataFrame to a html.
2879  
2880 Examples
2881 --------
2882 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({{'shape': ['square', 'circle', 'triangle'],
2883 ... 'degrees': [360, 360, 180],
2884 ... 'sides': [4, np.nan, 3]}})
2885  
2886 >>> df.to_xml() # doctest: +SKIP
2887 <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
2888 <data>
2889 <row>
2890 <index>0</index>
2891 <shape>square</shape>
2892 <degrees>360</degrees>
2893 <sides>4.0</sides>
2894 </row>
2895 <row>
2896 <index>1</index>
2897 <shape>circle</shape>
2898 <degrees>360</degrees>
2899 <sides/>
2900 </row>
2901 <row>
2902 <index>2</index>
2903 <shape>triangle</shape>
2904 <degrees>180</degrees>
2905 <sides>3.0</sides>
2906 </row>
2907 </data>
2908  
2909 >>> df.to_xml(attr_cols=[
2910 ... 'index', 'shape', 'degrees', 'sides'
2911 ... ]) # doctest: +SKIP
2912 <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
2913 <data>
2914 <row index="0" shape="square" degrees="360" sides="4.0"/>
2915 <row index="1" shape="circle" degrees="360"/>
2916 <row index="2" shape="triangle" degrees="180" sides="3.0"/>
2917 </data>
2918  
2919 >>> df.to_xml(namespaces={{"doc": "https://example.com"}},
2920 ... prefix="doc") # doctest: +SKIP
2921 <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
2922 <doc:data xmlns:doc="https://example.com">
2923 <doc:row>
2924 <doc:index>0</doc:index>
2925 <doc:shape>square</doc:shape>
2926 <doc:degrees>360</doc:degrees>
2927 <doc:sides>4.0</doc:sides>
2928 </doc:row>
2929 <doc:row>
2930 <doc:index>1</doc:index>
2931 <doc:shape>circle</doc:shape>
2932 <doc:degrees>360</doc:degrees>
2933 <doc:sides/>
2934 </doc:row>
2935 <doc:row>
2936 <doc:index>2</doc:index>
2937 <doc:shape>triangle</doc:shape>
2938 <doc:degrees>180</doc:degrees>
2939 <doc:sides>3.0</doc:sides>
2940 </doc:row>
2941 </doc:data>
2942 """
2943  
2944 from pandas.io.formats.xml import (
2945 EtreeXMLFormatter,
2946 LxmlXMLFormatter,
2947 )
2948  
2949 lxml = import_optional_dependency("lxml.etree", errors="ignore")
2950  
2951 TreeBuilder: type[EtreeXMLFormatter] | type[LxmlXMLFormatter]
2952  
2953 if parser == "lxml":
2954 if lxml is not None:
2955 TreeBuilder = LxmlXMLFormatter
2956 else:
2957 raise ImportError(
2958 "lxml not found, please install or use the etree parser."
2959 )
2960  
2961 elif parser == "etree":
2962 TreeBuilder = EtreeXMLFormatter
2963  
2964 else:
2965 raise ValueError("Values for parser can only be lxml or etree.")
2966  
2967 xml_formatter = TreeBuilder(
2968 self,
2969 path_or_buffer=path_or_buffer,
2970 index=index,
2971 root_name=root_name,
2972 row_name=row_name,
2973 na_rep=na_rep,
2974 attr_cols=attr_cols,
2975 elem_cols=elem_cols,
2976 namespaces=namespaces,
2977 prefix=prefix,
2978 encoding=encoding,
2979 xml_declaration=xml_declaration,
2980 pretty_print=pretty_print,
2981 stylesheet=stylesheet,
2982 compression=compression,
2983 storage_options=storage_options,
2984 )
2985  
2986 return xml_formatter.write_output()
2987

3133  
3134 def memory_usage(self, index: bool = True, deep: bool = False) -> Series:
3135 """
3136 Return the memory usage of each column in bytes.
3137  
3138 The memory usage can optionally include the contribution of
3139 the index and elements of `object` dtype.
3140  
3141 This value is displayed in `DataFrame.info` by default. This can be
3142 suppressed by setting ``pandas.options.display.memory_usage`` to False.
3143  
3144 Parameters
3145 ----------
3146 index : bool, default True
3147 Specifies whether to include the memory usage of the DataFrame's
3148 index in returned Series. If ``index=True``, the memory usage of
3149 the index is the first item in the output.
3150 deep : bool, default False
3151 If True, introspect the data deeply by interrogating
3152 `object` dtypes for system-level memory consumption, and include
3153 it in the returned values.
3154  
3155 Returns
3156 -------
3157 Series
3158 A Series whose index is the original column names and whose values
3159 is the memory usage of each column in bytes.
3160  
3161 See Also
3162 --------
3163 numpy.ndarray.nbytes : Total bytes consumed by the elements of an
3164 ndarray.
3165 Series.memory_usage : Bytes consumed by a Series.
3166 Categorical : Memory-efficient array for string values with
3167 many repeated values.
3168 DataFrame.info : Concise summary of a DataFrame.
3169  
3170 Examples
3171 --------
3172 >>> dtypes = ['int64', 'float64', 'complex128', 'object', 'bool']
3173 >>> data = dict([(t, np.ones(shape=5000, dtype=int).astype(t))
3174 ... for t in dtypes])
3175 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data)
3176 >>> df.head()
3177 int64 float64 complex128 object bool
3178 0 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3179 1 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3180 2 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3181 3 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3182 4 1 1.0 1.0+0.0j 1 True
3183  
3184 >>> df.memory_usage()
3185 Index 128
3186 int64 40000
3187 float64 40000
3188 complex128 80000
3189 object 40000
3190 bool 5000
3191 dtype: int64
3192  
3193 >>> df.memory_usage(index=False)
3194 int64 40000
3195 float64 40000
3196 complex128 80000
3197 object 40000
3198 bool 5000
3199 dtype: int64
3200  
3201 The memory footprint of `object` dtype columns is ignored by default:
3202  
3203 >>> df.memory_usage(deep=True)
3204 Index 128
3205 int64 40000
3206 float64 40000
3207 complex128 80000
3208 object 180000
3209 bool 5000
3210 dtype: int64
3211  
3212 Use a Categorical for efficient storage of an object-dtype column with
3213 many repeated values.
3214  
3215 >>> df['object'].astype('category').memory_usage(deep=True)
3216 5244
3217 """
3218 result = self._constructor_sliced(
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
3219 [c.memory_usage(index=False, deep=deep) for col, c in self.items()],
3220 index=self.columns,
3221 )
3222 if index:
3223 result = self._constructor_sliced(
3224 self.index.memory_usage(deep=deep), index=["Index"]
3225 ).append(result)
3226 return result
3227  
3228 def transpose(self, *args, copy: bool = False) -> DataFrame:
3229 """
3230 Transpose index and columns.
3231  
3232 Reflect the DataFrame over its main diagonal by writing rows as columns
3233 and vice-versa. The property :attr:`.T` is an accessor to the method
3234 :meth:`transpose`.
3235  
3236 Parameters
3237 ----------
3238 *args : tuple, optional
3239 Accepted for compatibility with NumPy.
3240 copy : bool, default False
3241 Whether to copy the data after transposing, even for DataFrames
3242 with a single dtype.
3243  
3244 Note that a copy is always required for mixed dtype DataFrames,
3245 or for DataFrames with any extension types.
3246  
3247 Returns
3248 -------
3249 DataFrame
3250 The transposed DataFrame.
3251  
3252 See Also
3253 --------
3254 numpy.transpose : Permute the dimensions of a given array.
3255  
3256 Notes
3257 -----
3258 Transposing a DataFrame with mixed dtypes will result in a homogeneous
3259 DataFrame with the `object` dtype. In such a case, a copy of the data
3260 is always made.
3261  
3262 Examples
3263 --------
3264 **Square DataFrame with homogeneous dtype**
3265  
3266 >>> d1 = {'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]}
3267 >>> df1 = pd.DataFrame(data=d1)
3268 >>> df1
3269 col1 col2
3270 0 1 3
3271 1 2 4
3272  
3273 >>> df1_transposed = df1.T # or df1.transpose()
3274 >>> df1_transposed
3275 0 1
3276 col1 1 2
3277 col2 3 4
3278  
3279 When the dtype is homogeneous in the original DataFrame, we get a
3280 transposed DataFrame with the same dtype:
3281  
3282 >>> df1.dtypes
3283 col1 int64
3284 col2 int64
3285 dtype: object
3286 >>> df1_transposed.dtypes
3287 0 int64
3288 1 int64
3289 dtype: object
3290  
3291 **Non-square DataFrame with mixed dtypes**
3292  
3293 >>> d2 = {'name': ['Alice', 'Bob'],
3294 ... 'score': [9.5, 8],
3295 ... 'employed': [False, True],
3296 ... 'kids': [0, 0]}
3297 >>> df2 = pd.DataFrame(data=d2)
3298 >>> df2
3299 name score employed kids
3300 0 Alice 9.5 False 0
3301 1 Bob 8.0 True 0
3302  
3303 >>> df2_transposed = df2.T # or df2.transpose()
3304 >>> df2_transposed
3305 0 1
3306 name Alice Bob
3307 score 9.5 8.0
3308 employed False True
3309 kids 0 0
3310  
3311 When the DataFrame has mixed dtypes, we get a transposed DataFrame with
3312 the `object` dtype:
3313  
3314 >>> df2.dtypes
3315 name object
3316 score float64
3317 employed bool
3318 kids int64
3319 dtype: object
3320 >>> df2_transposed.dtypes
3321 0 object
3322 1 object
3323 dtype: object
3324 """
3325 nv.validate_transpose(args, {})
3326 # construct the args
3327  
3328 dtypes = list(self.dtypes)
3329  
3330 if self._can_fast_transpose:
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
3331 # Note: tests pass without this, but this improves perf quite a bit.
3332 new_vals = self._values.T
3333 if copy:
3334 new_vals = new_vals.copy()
3335  
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
3336 result = self._constructor(new_vals, index=self.columns, columns=self.index)
3337  
3338 elif (
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
3339 self._is_homogeneous_type and dtypes and is_extension_array_dtype(dtypes[0])
3340 ):
  • E501 Line too long (87 > 79 characters)
3341 # We have EAs with the same dtype. We can preserve that dtype in transpose.
3342 dtype = dtypes[0]
3343 arr_type = dtype.construct_array_type()
3344 values = self.values
3345  
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
3346 new_values = [arr_type._from_sequence(row, dtype=dtype) for row in values]
3347 result = type(self)._from_arrays(
3348 new_values, index=self.columns, columns=self.index
3349 )
3350  
3351 else:
3352 new_arr = self.values.T
3353 if copy:
3354 new_arr = new_arr.copy()
  • E501 Line too long (87 > 79 characters)
3355 result = self._constructor(new_arr, index=self.columns, columns=self.index)
3356  
3357 return result.__finalize__(self, method="transpose")
3358  
3359 @property
3360 def T(self) -> DataFrame:
3361 return self.transpose()
3362  
3363 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
3364 # Indexing Methods
3365  
3366 def _ixs(self, i: int, axis: int = 0):
3367 """
3368 Parameters
3369 ----------
3370 i : int
3371 axis : int
3372  
3373 Notes
3374 -----
3375 If slice passed, the resulting data will be a view.
3376 """
3377 # irow
3378 if axis == 0:
3379 new_values = self._mgr.fast_xs(i)
3380  
3381 # if we are a copy, mark as such
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
3382 copy = isinstance(new_values, np.ndarray) and new_values.base is None
3383 result = self._constructor_sliced(
3384 new_values,
3385 index=self.columns,
3386 name=self.index[i],
3387 dtype=new_values.dtype,
3388 )
3389 result._set_is_copy(self, copy=copy)
3390 return result
3391  
3392 # icol
3393 else:
3394 label = self.columns[i]
3395  
3396 values = self._mgr.iget(i)
3397 result = self._box_col_values(values, i)
3398  
3399 # this is a cached value, mark it so
3400 result._set_as_cached(label, self)
3401 return result
3402  
3403 def _get_column_array(self, i: int) -> ArrayLike:
3404 """
3405 Get the values of the i'th column (ndarray or ExtensionArray, as stored
3406 in the Block)
3407 """
3408 return self._mgr.iget_values(i)
3409  
3410 def _iter_column_arrays(self) -> Iterator[ArrayLike]:
3411 """
3412 Iterate over the arrays of all columns in order.
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
3413 This returns the values as stored in the Block (ndarray or ExtensionArray).
3414 """
3415 for i in range(len(self.columns)):
3416 yield self._get_column_array(i)
3417  
3418 def __getitem__(self, key):
3419 key = lib.item_from_zerodim(key)
3420 key = com.apply_if_callable(key, self)
3421  
3422 if is_hashable(key):
3423 # shortcut if the key is in columns
3424 if self.columns.is_unique and key in self.columns:
3425 if isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex):
3426 return self._getitem_multilevel(key)
3427 return self._get_item_cache(key)
3428  
3429 # Do we have a slicer (on rows)?
3430 indexer = convert_to_index_sliceable(self, key)
3431 if indexer is not None:
3432 if isinstance(indexer, np.ndarray):
3433 indexer = lib.maybe_indices_to_slice(
3434 indexer.astype(np.intp, copy=False), len(self)
3435 )
3436 if isinstance(indexer, np.ndarray):
3437 # GH#43223 If we can not convert, use take
3438 return self.take(indexer, axis=0)
3439 # either we have a slice or we have a string that can be converted
3440 # to a slice for partial-string date indexing
3441 return self._slice(indexer, axis=0)
3442  
3443 # Do we have a (boolean) DataFrame?
3444 if isinstance(key, DataFrame):
3445 return self.where(key)
3446  
3447 # Do we have a (boolean) 1d indexer?
3448 if com.is_bool_indexer(key):
3449 return self._getitem_bool_array(key)
3450  
3451 # We are left with two options: a single key, and a collection of keys,
3452 # We interpret tuples as collections only for non-MultiIndex
3453 is_single_key = isinstance(key, tuple) or not is_list_like(key)
3454  
3455 if is_single_key:
3456 if self.columns.nlevels > 1:
3457 return self._getitem_multilevel(key)
3458 indexer = self.columns.get_loc(key)
3459 if is_integer(indexer):
3460 indexer = [indexer]
3461 else:
3462 if is_iterator(key):
3463 key = list(key)
3464 indexer = self.loc._get_listlike_indexer(key, axis=1)[1]
3465  
3466 # take() does not accept boolean indexers
3467 if getattr(indexer, "dtype", None) == bool:
3468 indexer = np.where(indexer)[0]
3469  
3470 data = self._take_with_is_copy(indexer, axis=1)
3471  
3472 if is_single_key:
3473 # What does looking for a single key in a non-unique index return?
3474 # The behavior is inconsistent. It returns a Series, except when
3475 # - the key itself is repeated (test on data.shape, #9519), or
3476 # - we have a MultiIndex on columns (test on self.columns, #21309)
3477 if data.shape[1] == 1 and not isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex):
3478 # GH#26490 using data[key] can cause RecursionError
3479 return data._get_item_cache(key)
3480  
3481 return data
3482  
3483 def _getitem_bool_array(self, key):
3484 # also raises Exception if object array with NA values
3485 # warning here just in case -- previously __setitem__ was
3486 # reindexing but __getitem__ was not; it seems more reasonable to
3487 # go with the __setitem__ behavior since that is more consistent
3488 # with all other indexing behavior
3489 if isinstance(key, Series) and not key.index.equals(self.index):
3490 warnings.warn(
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
3491 "Boolean Series key will be reindexed to match DataFrame index.",
3492 UserWarning,
3493 stacklevel=3,
3494 )
3495 elif len(key) != len(self.index):
3496 raise ValueError(
3497 f"Item wrong length {len(key)} instead of {len(self.index)}."
3498 )
3499  
3500 # check_bool_indexer will throw exception if Series key cannot
3501 # be reindexed to match DataFrame rows
3502 key = check_bool_indexer(self.index, key)
3503 indexer = key.nonzero()[0]
3504 return self._take_with_is_copy(indexer, axis=0)
3505  
3506 def _getitem_multilevel(self, key):
3507 # self.columns is a MultiIndex
3508 loc = self.columns.get_loc(key)
3509 if isinstance(loc, (slice, np.ndarray)):
3510 new_columns = self.columns[loc]
3511 result_columns = maybe_droplevels(new_columns, key)
3512 if self._is_mixed_type:
3513 result = self.reindex(columns=new_columns)
3514 result.columns = result_columns
3515 else:
3516 new_values = self.values[:, loc]
3517 result = self._constructor(
3518 new_values, index=self.index, columns=result_columns
3519 )
3520 result = result.__finalize__(self)
3521  
3522 # If there is only one column being returned, and its name is
3523 # either an empty string, or a tuple with an empty string as its
3524 # first element, then treat the empty string as a placeholder
3525 # and return the column as if the user had provided that empty
3526 # string in the key. If the result is a Series, exclude the
3527 # implied empty string from its name.
3528 if len(result.columns) == 1:
3529 top = result.columns[0]
3530 if isinstance(top, tuple):
3531 top = top[0]
3532 if top == "":
3533 result = result[""]
3534 if isinstance(result, Series):
3535 result = self._constructor_sliced(
3536 result, index=self.index, name=key
3537 )
3538  
3539 result._set_is_copy(self)
3540 return result
3541 else:
3542 # loc is neither a slice nor ndarray, so must be an int
3543 return self._ixs(loc, axis=1)
3544  
3545 def _get_value(self, index, col, takeable: bool = False) -> Scalar:
3546 """
3547 Quickly retrieve single value at passed column and index.
3548  
3549 Parameters
3550 ----------
3551 index : row label
3552 col : column label
3553 takeable : interpret the index/col as indexers, default False
3554  
3555 Returns
3556 -------
3557 scalar
3558  
3559 Notes
3560 -----
3561 Assumes that index and columns both have ax._index_as_unique;
3562 caller is responsible for checking.
3563 """
3564 if takeable:
3565 series = self._ixs(col, axis=1)
3566 return series._values[index]
3567  
3568 series = self._get_item_cache(col)
3569 engine = self.index._engine
3570  
3571 if isinstance(self.index, CategoricalIndex):
3572 # Trying to use the engine fastpath may give incorrect results
3573 # if our categories are integers that dont match our codes
3574 col = self.columns.get_loc(col)
3575 index = self.index.get_loc(index)
3576 return self._get_value(index, col, takeable=True)
3577  
3578 try:
3579 loc = engine.get_loc(index)
3580 return series._values[loc]
3581 except AttributeError:
3582 # IntervalTree has no get_loc
3583 col = self.columns.get_loc(col)
3584 index = self.index.get_loc(index)
3585 return self._get_value(index, col, takeable=True)
3586  
3587 def __setitem__(self, key, value):
3588 key = com.apply_if_callable(key, self)
3589  
3590 # see if we can slice the rows
3591 indexer = convert_to_index_sliceable(self, key)
3592 if indexer is not None:
3593 # either we have a slice or we have a string that can be converted
3594 # to a slice for partial-string date indexing
3595 return self._setitem_slice(indexer, value)
3596  
3597 if isinstance(key, DataFrame) or getattr(key, "ndim", None) == 2:
3598 self._setitem_frame(key, value)
3599 elif isinstance(key, (Series, np.ndarray, list, Index)):
3600 self._setitem_array(key, value)
3601 elif isinstance(value, DataFrame):
3602 self._set_item_frame_value(key, value)
3603 elif (
3604 is_list_like(value)
3605 and not self.columns.is_unique
3606 and 1 < len(self.columns.get_indexer_for([key])) == len(value)
3607 ):
3608 # Column to set is duplicated
3609 self._setitem_array([key], value)
3610 else:
3611 # set column
3612 self._set_item(key, value)
3613  
3614 def _setitem_slice(self, key: slice, value):
3615 # NB: we can't just use self.loc[key] = value because that
3616 # operates on labels and we need to operate positional for
3617 # backwards-compat, xref GH#31469
3618 self._check_setitem_copy()
3619 self.iloc[key] = value
3620  
3621 def _setitem_array(self, key, value):
3622 # also raises Exception if object array with NA values
3623 if com.is_bool_indexer(key):
3624 # bool indexer is indexing along rows
3625 if len(key) != len(self.index):
3626 raise ValueError(
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
3627 f"Item wrong length {len(key)} instead of {len(self.index)}!"
3628 )
3629 key = check_bool_indexer(self.index, key)
3630 indexer = key.nonzero()[0]
3631 self._check_setitem_copy()
3632 if isinstance(value, DataFrame):
3633 # GH#39931 reindex since iloc does not align
3634 value = value.reindex(self.index.take(indexer))
3635 self.iloc[indexer] = value
3636  
3637 else:
3638 if isinstance(value, DataFrame):
3639 check_key_length(self.columns, key, value)
3640 for k1, k2 in zip(key, value.columns):
3641 self[k1] = value[k2]
3642  
3643 elif not is_list_like(value):
3644 for col in key:
3645 self[col] = value
3646  
3647 elif isinstance(value, np.ndarray) and value.ndim == 2:
3648 self._iset_not_inplace(key, value)
3649  
3650 elif np.ndim(value) > 1:
3651 # list of lists
3652 value = DataFrame(value).values
3653 return self._setitem_array(key, value)
3654  
3655 else:
3656 self._iset_not_inplace(key, value)
3657  
3658 def _iset_not_inplace(self, key, value):
3659 # GH#39510 when setting with df[key] = obj with a list-like key and
3660 # list-like value, we iterate over those listlikes and set columns
3661 # one at a time. This is different from dispatching to
3662 # `self.loc[:, key]= value` because loc.__setitem__ may overwrite
3663 # data inplace, whereas this will insert new arrays.
3664  
3665 def igetitem(obj, i: int):
3666 # Note: we catch DataFrame obj before getting here, but
3667 # hypothetically would return obj.iloc[:, i]
3668 if isinstance(obj, np.ndarray):
3669 return obj[..., i]
3670 else:
3671 return obj[i]
3672  
3673 if self.columns.is_unique:
3674 if np.shape(value)[-1] != len(key):
3675 raise ValueError("Columns must be same length as key")
3676  
3677 for i, col in enumerate(key):
3678 self[col] = igetitem(value, i)
3679  
3680 else:
3681  
3682 ilocs = self.columns.get_indexer_non_unique(key)[0]
3683 if (ilocs < 0).any():
3684 # key entries not in self.columns
3685 raise NotImplementedError
3686  
3687 if np.shape(value)[-1] != len(ilocs):
3688 raise ValueError("Columns must be same length as key")
3689  
3690 assert np.ndim(value) <= 2
3691  
3692 orig_columns = self.columns
3693  
3694 # Using self.iloc[:, i] = ... may set values inplace, which
3695 # by convention we do not do in __setitem__
3696 try:
3697 self.columns = Index(range(len(self.columns)))
3698 for i, iloc in enumerate(ilocs):
3699 self[iloc] = igetitem(value, i)
3700 finally:
3701 self.columns = orig_columns
3702  
3703 def _setitem_frame(self, key, value):
3704 # support boolean setting with DataFrame input, e.g.
3705 # df[df > df2] = 0
3706 if isinstance(key, np.ndarray):
3707 if key.shape != self.shape:
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
3708 raise ValueError("Array conditional must be same shape as self")
3709 key = self._constructor(key, **self._construct_axes_dict())
3710  
3711 if key.size and not is_bool_dtype(key.values):
3712 raise TypeError(
3713 "Must pass DataFrame or 2-d ndarray with boolean values only"
3714 )
3715  
3716 self._check_inplace_setting(value)
3717 self._check_setitem_copy()
3718 self._where(-key, value, inplace=True)
3719  
3720 def _set_item_frame_value(self, key, value: DataFrame) -> None:
3721 self._ensure_valid_index(value)
3722  
3723 # align columns
3724 if key in self.columns:
3725 loc = self.columns.get_loc(key)
3726 cols = self.columns[loc]
3727 len_cols = 1 if is_scalar(cols) else len(cols)
3728 if len_cols != len(value.columns):
3729 raise ValueError("Columns must be same length as key")
3730  
3731 # align right-hand-side columns if self.columns
3732 # is multi-index and self[key] is a sub-frame
3733 if isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex) and isinstance(
3734 loc, (slice, Series, np.ndarray, Index)
3735 ):
3736 cols = maybe_droplevels(cols, key)
3737 if len(cols) and not cols.equals(value.columns):
3738 value = value.reindex(cols, axis=1)
3739  
3740 # now align rows
3741 arraylike = _reindex_for_setitem(value, self.index)
3742 self._set_item_mgr(key, arraylike)
3743  
3744 def _iset_item_mgr(self, loc: int | slice | np.ndarray, value) -> None:
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
3745 # when called from _set_item_mgr loc can be anything returned from get_loc
3746 self._mgr.iset(loc, value)
3747 self._clear_item_cache()
3748  
3749 def _set_item_mgr(self, key, value: ArrayLike) -> None:
3750 try:
3751 loc = self._info_axis.get_loc(key)
3752 except KeyError:
3753 # This item wasn't present, just insert at end
3754 self._mgr.insert(len(self._info_axis), key, value)
3755 else:
3756 self._iset_item_mgr(loc, value)
3757  
3758 # check if we are modifying a copy
3759 # try to set first as we want an invalid
3760 # value exception to occur first
3761 if len(self):
3762 self._check_setitem_copy(stacklevel=5)
3763  
3764 def _iset_item(self, loc: int, value) -> None:
3765 arraylike = self._sanitize_column(value)
3766 self._iset_item_mgr(loc, arraylike)
3767  
3768 # check if we are modifying a copy
3769 # try to set first as we want an invalid
3770 # value exception to occur first
3771 if len(self):
3772 self._check_setitem_copy()
3773  
3774 def _set_item(self, key, value) -> None:
3775 """
3776 Add series to DataFrame in specified column.
3777  
3778 If series is a numpy-array (not a Series/TimeSeries), it must be the
3779 same length as the DataFrames index or an error will be thrown.
3780  
3781 Series/TimeSeries will be conformed to the DataFrames index to
3782 ensure homogeneity.
3783 """
3784 value = self._sanitize_column(value)
3785  
3786 if (
3787 key in self.columns
3788 and value.ndim == 1
3789 and not is_extension_array_dtype(value)
3790 ):
3791 # broadcast across multiple columns if necessary
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
3792 if not self.columns.is_unique or isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex):
3793 existing_piece = self[key]
3794 if isinstance(existing_piece, DataFrame):
3795 value = np.tile(value, (len(existing_piece.columns), 1)).T
3796  
3797 self._set_item_mgr(key, value)
3798  
3799 def _set_value(
3800 self, index: IndexLabel, col, value: Scalar, takeable: bool = False
3801 ) -> None:
3802 """
3803 Put single value at passed column and index.
3804  
3805 Parameters
3806 ----------
3807 index : Label
3808 row label
3809 col : Label
3810 column label
3811 value : scalar
3812 takeable : bool, default False
3813 Sets whether or not index/col interpreted as indexers
3814 """
3815 try:
3816 if takeable:
3817 series = self._ixs(col, axis=1)
3818 series._set_value(index, value, takeable=True)
3819 return
3820  
3821 series = self._get_item_cache(col)
3822 engine = self.index._engine
3823 loc = engine.get_loc(index)
3824 validate_numeric_casting(series.dtype, value)
3825  
3826 series._values[loc] = value
3827 # Note: trying to use series._set_value breaks tests in
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
3828 # tests.frame.indexing.test_indexing and tests.indexing.test_partial
3829 except (KeyError, TypeError):
3830 # set using a non-recursive method & reset the cache
3831 if takeable:
3832 self.iloc[index, col] = value
3833 else:
3834 self.loc[index, col] = value
3835 self._item_cache.pop(col, None)
3836  
3837 def _ensure_valid_index(self, value) -> None:
3838 """
3839 Ensure that if we don't have an index, that we can create one from the
3840 passed value.
3841 """
3842 # GH5632, make sure that we are a Series convertible
3843 if not len(self.index) and is_list_like(value) and len(value):
3844 if not isinstance(value, DataFrame):
3845 try:
3846 value = Series(value)
3847 except (ValueError, NotImplementedError, TypeError) as err:
3848 raise ValueError(
3849 "Cannot set a frame with no defined index "
3850 "and a value that cannot be converted to a Series"
3851 ) from err
3852  
3853 # GH31368 preserve name of index
3854 index_copy = value.index.copy()
3855 if self.index.name is not None:
3856 index_copy.name = self.index.name
3857  
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
3858 self._mgr = self._mgr.reindex_axis(index_copy, axis=1, fill_value=np.nan)
3859  
3860 def _box_col_values(self, values, loc: int) -> Series:
3861 """
3862 Provide boxed values for a column.
3863 """
3864 # Lookup in columns so that if e.g. a str datetime was passed
3865 # we attach the Timestamp object as the name.
3866 name = self.columns[loc]
3867 klass = self._constructor_sliced
3868 return klass(values, index=self.index, name=name, fastpath=True)
3869  
3870 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
3871 # Lookup Caching
3872  
3873 def _clear_item_cache(self) -> None:
3874 self._item_cache.clear()
3875  
3876 def _get_item_cache(self, item: Hashable) -> Series:
3877 """Return the cached item, item represents a label indexer."""
3878 cache = self._item_cache
3879 res = cache.get(item)
3880 if res is None:
3881 # All places that call _get_item_cache have unique columns,
3882 # pending resolution of GH#33047
3883  
3884 loc = self.columns.get_loc(item)
3885 values = self._mgr.iget(loc)
3886 res = self._box_col_values(values, loc).__finalize__(self)
3887  
3888 cache[item] = res
3889 res._set_as_cached(item, self)
3890  
3891 # for a chain
3892 res._is_copy = self._is_copy
3893 return res
3894  
3895 def _reset_cacher(self) -> None:
3896 # no-op for DataFrame
3897 pass
3898  
3899 def _maybe_cache_changed(self, item, value: Series) -> None:
3900 """
3901 The object has called back to us saying maybe it has changed.
3902 """
3903 loc = self._info_axis.get_loc(item)
3904 arraylike = value._values
3905 self._mgr.iset(loc, arraylike)
3906  
3907 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
3908 # Unsorted
3909  
3910 def query(self, expr: str, inplace: bool = False, **kwargs):
3911 """
3912 Query the columns of a DataFrame with a boolean expression.
3913  
3914 Parameters
3915 ----------
3916 expr : str
3917 The query string to evaluate.
3918  
3919 You can refer to variables
3920 in the environment by prefixing them with an '@' character like
3921 ``@a + b``.
3922  
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
3923 You can refer to column names that are not valid Python variable names
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
3924 by surrounding them in backticks. Thus, column names containing spaces
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
3925 or punctuations (besides underscores) or starting with digits must be
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
3926 surrounded by backticks. (For example, a column named "Area (cm^2)" would
  • E501 Line too long (87 > 79 characters)
3927 be referenced as ```Area (cm^2)```). Column names which are Python keywords
3928 (like "list", "for", "import", etc) cannot be used.
3929  
3930 For example, if one of your columns is called ``a a`` and you want
3931 to sum it with ``b``, your query should be ```a a` + b``.
3932  
3933 .. versionadded:: 0.25.0
3934 Backtick quoting introduced.
3935  
3936 .. versionadded:: 1.0.0
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
3937 Expanding functionality of backtick quoting for more than only spaces.
3938  
3939 inplace : bool
3940 Whether the query should modify the data in place or return
3941 a modified copy.
3942 **kwargs
3943 See the documentation for :func:`eval` for complete details
3944 on the keyword arguments accepted by :meth:`DataFrame.query`.
3945  
3946 Returns
3947 -------
3948 DataFrame or None
3949 DataFrame resulting from the provided query expression or
3950 None if ``inplace=True``.
3951  
3952 See Also
3953 --------
3954 eval : Evaluate a string describing operations on
3955 DataFrame columns.
3956 DataFrame.eval : Evaluate a string describing operations on
3957 DataFrame columns.
3958  
3959 Notes
3960 -----
3961 The result of the evaluation of this expression is first passed to
3962 :attr:`DataFrame.loc` and if that fails because of a
3963 multidimensional key (e.g., a DataFrame) then the result will be passed
3964 to :meth:`DataFrame.__getitem__`.
3965  
3966 This method uses the top-level :func:`eval` function to
3967 evaluate the passed query.
3968  
3969 The :meth:`~pandas.DataFrame.query` method uses a slightly
3970 modified Python syntax by default. For example, the ``&`` and ``|``
3971 (bitwise) operators have the precedence of their boolean cousins,
3972 :keyword:`and` and :keyword:`or`. This *is* syntactically valid Python,
3973 however the semantics are different.
3974  
3975 You can change the semantics of the expression by passing the keyword
3976 argument ``parser='python'``. This enforces the same semantics as
3977 evaluation in Python space. Likewise, you can pass ``engine='python'``
3978 to evaluate an expression using Python itself as a backend. This is not
3979 recommended as it is inefficient compared to using ``numexpr`` as the
3980 engine.
3981  
3982 The :attr:`DataFrame.index` and
3983 :attr:`DataFrame.columns` attributes of the
3984 :class:`~pandas.DataFrame` instance are placed in the query namespace
3985 by default, which allows you to treat both the index and columns of the
3986 frame as a column in the frame.
3987 The identifier ``index`` is used for the frame index; you can also
3988 use the name of the index to identify it in a query. Please note that
3989 Python keywords may not be used as identifiers.
3990  
3991 For further details and examples see the ``query`` documentation in
3992 :ref:`indexing <indexing.query>`.
3993  
3994 *Backtick quoted variables*
3995  
3996 Backtick quoted variables are parsed as literal Python code and
3997 are converted internally to a Python valid identifier.
3998 This can lead to the following problems.
3999  
4000 During parsing a number of disallowed characters inside the backtick
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
4001 quoted string are replaced by strings that are allowed as a Python identifier.
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
4002 These characters include all operators in Python, the space character, the
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
4003 question mark, the exclamation mark, the dollar sign, and the euro sign.
4004 For other characters that fall outside the ASCII range (U+0001..U+007F)
4005 and those that are not further specified in PEP 3131,
4006 the query parser will raise an error.
4007 This excludes whitespace different than the space character,
4008 but also the hashtag (as it is used for comments) and the backtick
4009 itself (backtick can also not be escaped).
4010  
4011 In a special case, quotes that make a pair around a backtick can
4012 confuse the parser.
4013 For example, ```it's` > `that's``` will raise an error,
4014 as it forms a quoted string (``'s > `that'``) with a backtick inside.
4015  
4016 See also the Python documentation about lexical analysis
4017 (https://docs.python.org/3/reference/lexical_analysis.html)
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
4018 in combination with the source code in :mod:`pandas.core.computation.parsing`.
4019  
4020 Examples
4021 --------
4022 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': range(1, 6),
4023 ... 'B': range(10, 0, -2),
4024 ... 'C C': range(10, 5, -1)})
4025 >>> df
4026 A B C C
4027 0 1 10 10
4028 1 2 8 9
4029 2 3 6 8
4030 3 4 4 7
4031 4 5 2 6
4032 >>> df.query('A > B')
4033 A B C C
4034 4 5 2 6
4035  
4036 The previous expression is equivalent to
4037  
4038 >>> df[df.A > df.B]
4039 A B C C
4040 4 5 2 6
4041  
4042 For columns with spaces in their name, you can use backtick quoting.
4043  
4044 >>> df.query('B == `C C`')
4045 A B C C
4046 0 1 10 10
4047  
4048 The previous expression is equivalent to
4049  
4050 >>> df[df.B == df['C C']]
4051 A B C C
4052 0 1 10 10
4053 """
4054 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
4055 if not isinstance(expr, str):
4056 msg = f"expr must be a string to be evaluated, {type(expr)} given"
4057 raise ValueError(msg)
4058 kwargs["level"] = kwargs.pop("level", 0) + 1
4059 kwargs["target"] = None
4060 res = self.eval(expr, **kwargs)
4061  
4062 try:
4063 result = self.loc[res]
4064 except ValueError:
4065 # when res is multi-dimensional loc raises, but this is sometimes a
4066 # valid query
4067 result = self[res]
4068  
4069 if inplace:
4070 self._update_inplace(result)
4071 return None
4072 else:
4073 return result
4074  
4075 def eval(self, expr: str, inplace: bool = False, **kwargs):
4076 """
4077 Evaluate a string describing operations on DataFrame columns.
4078  
4079 Operates on columns only, not specific rows or elements. This allows
4080 `eval` to run arbitrary code, which can make you vulnerable to code
4081 injection if you pass user input to this function.
4082  
4083 Parameters
4084 ----------
4085 expr : str
4086 The expression string to evaluate.
4087 inplace : bool, default False
4088 If the expression contains an assignment, whether to perform the
4089 operation inplace and mutate the existing DataFrame. Otherwise,
4090 a new DataFrame is returned.
4091 **kwargs
4092 See the documentation for :func:`eval` for complete details
4093 on the keyword arguments accepted by
4094 :meth:`~pandas.DataFrame.query`.
4095  
4096 Returns
4097 -------
4098 ndarray, scalar, pandas object, or None
4099 The result of the evaluation or None if ``inplace=True``.
4100  
4101 See Also
4102 --------
4103 DataFrame.query : Evaluates a boolean expression to query the columns
4104 of a frame.
4105 DataFrame.assign : Can evaluate an expression or function to create new
4106 values for a column.
4107 eval : Evaluate a Python expression as a string using various
4108 backends.
4109  
4110 Notes
4111 -----
4112 For more details see the API documentation for :func:`~eval`.
4113 For detailed examples see :ref:`enhancing performance with eval
4114 <enhancingperf.eval>`.
4115  
4116 Examples
4117 --------
4118 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': range(1, 6), 'B': range(10, 0, -2)})
4119 >>> df
4120 A B
4121 0 1 10
4122 1 2 8
4123 2 3 6
4124 3 4 4
4125 4 5 2
4126 >>> df.eval('A + B')
4127 0 11
4128 1 10
4129 2 9
4130 3 8
4131 4 7
4132 dtype: int64
4133  
4134 Assignment is allowed though by default the original DataFrame is not
4135 modified.
4136  
4137 >>> df.eval('C = A + B')
4138 A B C
4139 0 1 10 11
4140 1 2 8 10
4141 2 3 6 9
4142 3 4 4 8
4143 4 5 2 7
4144 >>> df
4145 A B
4146 0 1 10
4147 1 2 8
4148 2 3 6
4149 3 4 4
4150 4 5 2
4151  
4152 Use ``inplace=True`` to modify the original DataFrame.
4153  
4154 >>> df.eval('C = A + B', inplace=True)
4155 >>> df
4156 A B C
4157 0 1 10 11
4158 1 2 8 10
4159 2 3 6 9
4160 3 4 4 8
4161 4 5 2 7
4162  
4163 Multiple columns can be assigned to using multi-line expressions:
4164  
4165 >>> df.eval(
4166 ... '''
4167 ... C = A + B
4168 ... D = A - B
4169 ... '''
4170 ... )
4171 A B C D
4172 0 1 10 11 -9
4173 1 2 8 10 -6
4174 2 3 6 9 -3
4175 3 4 4 8 0
4176 4 5 2 7 3
4177 """
4178 from pandas.core.computation.eval import eval as _eval
4179  
4180 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
4181 resolvers = kwargs.pop("resolvers", None)
4182 kwargs["level"] = kwargs.pop("level", 0) + 1
4183 if resolvers is None:
4184 index_resolvers = self._get_index_resolvers()
4185 column_resolvers = self._get_cleaned_column_resolvers()
4186 resolvers = column_resolvers, index_resolvers
4187 if "target" not in kwargs:
4188 kwargs["target"] = self
4189 kwargs["resolvers"] = kwargs.get("resolvers", ()) + tuple(resolvers)
4190  
4191 return _eval(expr, inplace=inplace, **kwargs)
4192  
4193 def select_dtypes(self, include=None, exclude=None) -> DataFrame:
4194 """
4195 Return a subset of the DataFrame's columns based on the column dtypes.
4196  
4197 Parameters
4198 ----------
4199 include, exclude : scalar or list-like
4200 A selection of dtypes or strings to be included/excluded. At least
4201 one of these parameters must be supplied.
4202  
4203 Returns
4204 -------
4205 DataFrame
4206 The subset of the frame including the dtypes in ``include`` and
4207 excluding the dtypes in ``exclude``.
4208  
4209 Raises
4210 ------
4211 ValueError
4212 * If both of ``include`` and ``exclude`` are empty
4213 * If ``include`` and ``exclude`` have overlapping elements
4214 * If any kind of string dtype is passed in.
4215  
4216 See Also
4217 --------
4218 DataFrame.dtypes: Return Series with the data type of each column.
4219  
4220 Notes
4221 -----
4222 * To select all *numeric* types, use ``np.number`` or ``'number'``
4223 * To select strings you must use the ``object`` dtype, but note that
4224 this will return *all* object dtype columns
4225 * See the `numpy dtype hierarchy
4226 <https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/arrays.scalars.html>`__
4227 * To select datetimes, use ``np.datetime64``, ``'datetime'`` or
4228 ``'datetime64'``
4229 * To select timedeltas, use ``np.timedelta64``, ``'timedelta'`` or
4230 ``'timedelta64'``
4231 * To select Pandas categorical dtypes, use ``'category'``
4232 * To select Pandas datetimetz dtypes, use ``'datetimetz'`` (new in
4233 0.20.0) or ``'datetime64[ns, tz]'``
4234  
4235 Examples
4236 --------
4237 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [1, 2] * 3,
4238 ... 'b': [True, False] * 3,
4239 ... 'c': [1.0, 2.0] * 3})
4240 >>> df
4241 a b c
4242 0 1 True 1.0
4243 1 2 False 2.0
4244 2 1 True 1.0
4245 3 2 False 2.0
4246 4 1 True 1.0
4247 5 2 False 2.0
4248  
4249 >>> df.select_dtypes(include='bool')
4250 b
4251 0 True
4252 1 False
4253 2 True
4254 3 False
4255 4 True
4256 5 False
4257  
4258 >>> df.select_dtypes(include=['float64'])
4259 c
4260 0 1.0
4261 1 2.0
4262 2 1.0
4263 3 2.0
4264 4 1.0
4265 5 2.0
4266  
4267 >>> df.select_dtypes(exclude=['int64'])
4268 b c
4269 0 True 1.0
4270 1 False 2.0
4271 2 True 1.0
4272 3 False 2.0
4273 4 True 1.0
4274 5 False 2.0
4275 """
4276 if not is_list_like(include):
4277 include = (include,) if include is not None else ()
4278 if not is_list_like(exclude):
4279 exclude = (exclude,) if exclude is not None else ()
4280  
4281 selection = (frozenset(include), frozenset(exclude))
4282  
4283 if not any(selection):
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
4284 raise ValueError("at least one of include or exclude must be nonempty")
4285  
4286 # convert the myriad valid dtypes object to a single representation
4287 def check_int_infer_dtype(dtypes):
4288 converted_dtypes = []
4289 for dtype in dtypes:
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
4290 # Numpy maps int to different types (int32, in64) on Windows and Linux
4291 # see https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/9464
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
4292 if (isinstance(dtype, str) and dtype == "int") or (dtype is int):
4293 converted_dtypes.append(np.int32)
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
4294 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
4295 # "Type[signedinteger[Any]]"; expected "Type[signedinteger[Any]]"
4296 converted_dtypes.append(np.int64) # type: ignore[arg-type]
4297 else:
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
4298 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
4299 # "Union[dtype[Any], ExtensionDtype]"; expected
4300 # "Type[signedinteger[Any]]"
4301 converted_dtypes.append(
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
4302 infer_dtype_from_object(dtype) # type: ignore[arg-type]
4303 )
4304 return frozenset(converted_dtypes)
4305  
4306 include = check_int_infer_dtype(include)
4307 exclude = check_int_infer_dtype(exclude)
4308  
4309 for dtypes in (include, exclude):
4310 invalidate_string_dtypes(dtypes)
4311  
4312 # can't both include AND exclude!
4313 if not include.isdisjoint(exclude):
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
4314 raise ValueError(f"include and exclude overlap on {(include & exclude)}")
4315  
4316 # We raise when both include and exclude are empty
4317 # Hence, we can just shrink the columns we want to keep
4318 keep_these = np.full(self.shape[1], True)
4319  
4320 def extract_unique_dtypes_from_dtypes_set(
4321 dtypes_set: frozenset[Dtype], unique_dtypes: np.ndarray
4322 ) -> list[Dtype]:
4323 extracted_dtypes = [
4324 unique_dtype
4325 for unique_dtype in unique_dtypes
4326 if (
4327 issubclass(
4328 # error: Argument 1 to "tuple" has incompatible type
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
4329 # "FrozenSet[Union[ExtensionDtype, Union[str, Any], Type[str],
4330 # Type[float], Type[int], Type[complex], Type[bool],
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
4331 # Type[object]]]"; expected "Iterable[Union[type, Tuple[Any,
4332 # ...]]]"
4333 unique_dtype.type,
4334 tuple(dtypes_set), # type: ignore[arg-type]
4335 )
4336 or (
4337 np.number in dtypes_set
4338 and getattr(unique_dtype, "_is_numeric", False)
4339 )
4340 )
4341 ]
4342 return extracted_dtypes
4343  
4344 unique_dtypes = self.dtypes.unique()
4345  
4346 if include:
4347 included_dtypes = extract_unique_dtypes_from_dtypes_set(
4348 include, unique_dtypes
4349 )
4350 keep_these &= self.dtypes.isin(included_dtypes)
4351  
4352 if exclude:
4353 excluded_dtypes = extract_unique_dtypes_from_dtypes_set(
4354 exclude, unique_dtypes
4355 )
4356 keep_these &= ~self.dtypes.isin(excluded_dtypes)
4357  
4358 # error: "ndarray" has no attribute "values"
4359 return self.iloc[:, keep_these.values] # type: ignore[attr-defined]
4360  
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
4361 def insert(self, loc, column, value, allow_duplicates: bool = False) -> None:
4362 """
4363 Insert column into DataFrame at specified location.
4364  
4365 Raises a ValueError if `column` is already contained in the DataFrame,
4366 unless `allow_duplicates` is set to True.
4367  
4368 Parameters
4369 ----------
4370 loc : int
4371 Insertion index. Must verify 0 <= loc <= len(columns).
4372 column : str, number, or hashable object
4373 Label of the inserted column.
4374 value : int, Series, or array-like
4375 allow_duplicates : bool, optional
4376  
4377 See Also
4378 --------
4379 Index.insert : Insert new item by index.
4380  
4381 Examples
4382 --------
4383 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]})
4384 >>> df
4385 col1 col2
4386 0 1 3
4387 1 2 4
4388 >>> df.insert(1, "newcol", [99, 99])
4389 >>> df
4390 col1 newcol col2
4391 0 1 99 3
4392 1 2 99 4
4393 >>> df.insert(0, "col1", [100, 100], allow_duplicates=True)
4394 >>> df
4395 col1 col1 newcol col2
4396 0 100 1 99 3
4397 1 100 2 99 4
4398  
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
4399 Notice that pandas uses index alignment in case of `value` from type `Series`:
4400  
4401 >>> df.insert(0, "col0", pd.Series([5, 6], index=[1, 2]))
4402 >>> df
4403 col0 col1 col1 newcol col2
4404 0 NaN 100 1 99 3
4405 1 5.0 100 2 99 4
4406 """
4407 if allow_duplicates and not self.flags.allows_duplicate_labels:
4408 raise ValueError(
4409 "Cannot specify 'allow_duplicates=True' when "
4410 "'self.flags.allows_duplicate_labels' is False."
4411 )
4412 if not allow_duplicates and column in self.columns:
4413 # Should this be a different kind of error??
4414 raise ValueError(f"cannot insert {column}, already exists")
4415 if not isinstance(loc, int):
4416 raise TypeError("loc must be int")
4417  
4418 value = self._sanitize_column(value)
4419 self._mgr.insert(loc, column, value)
4420  
4421 def assign(self, **kwargs) -> DataFrame:
4422 r"""
4423 Assign new columns to a DataFrame.
4424  
4425 Returns a new object with all original columns in addition to new ones.
4426 Existing columns that are re-assigned will be overwritten.
4427  
4428 Parameters
4429 ----------
4430 **kwargs : dict of {str: callable or Series}
4431 The column names are keywords. If the values are
4432 callable, they are computed on the DataFrame and
4433 assigned to the new columns. The callable must not
4434 change input DataFrame (though pandas doesn't check it).
4435 If the values are not callable, (e.g. a Series, scalar, or array),
4436 they are simply assigned.
4437  
4438 Returns
4439 -------
4440 DataFrame
4441 A new DataFrame with the new columns in addition to
4442 all the existing columns.
4443  
4444 Notes
4445 -----
4446 Assigning multiple columns within the same ``assign`` is possible.
4447 Later items in '\*\*kwargs' may refer to newly created or modified
4448 columns in 'df'; items are computed and assigned into 'df' in order.
4449  
4450 Examples
4451 --------
4452 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'temp_c': [17.0, 25.0]},
4453 ... index=['Portland', 'Berkeley'])
4454 >>> df
4455 temp_c
4456 Portland 17.0
4457 Berkeley 25.0
4458  
4459 Where the value is a callable, evaluated on `df`:
4460  
4461 >>> df.assign(temp_f=lambda x: x.temp_c * 9 / 5 + 32)
4462 temp_c temp_f
4463 Portland 17.0 62.6
4464 Berkeley 25.0 77.0
4465  
4466 Alternatively, the same behavior can be achieved by directly
4467 referencing an existing Series or sequence:
4468  
4469 >>> df.assign(temp_f=df['temp_c'] * 9 / 5 + 32)
4470 temp_c temp_f
4471 Portland 17.0 62.6
4472 Berkeley 25.0 77.0
4473  
4474 You can create multiple columns within the same assign where one
4475 of the columns depends on another one defined within the same assign:
4476  
4477 >>> df.assign(temp_f=lambda x: x['temp_c'] * 9 / 5 + 32,
4478 ... temp_k=lambda x: (x['temp_f'] + 459.67) * 5 / 9)
4479 temp_c temp_f temp_k
4480 Portland 17.0 62.6 290.15
4481 Berkeley 25.0 77.0 298.15
4482 """
4483 data = self.copy()
4484  
4485 for k, v in kwargs.items():
4486 data[k] = com.apply_if_callable(v, data)
4487 return data
4488  
4489 def _sanitize_column(self, value) -> ArrayLike:
4490 """
4491 Ensures new columns (which go into the BlockManager as new blocks) are
4492 always copied and converted into an array.
4493  
4494 Parameters
4495 ----------
4496 value : scalar, Series, or array-like
4497  
4498 Returns
4499 -------
4500 numpy.ndarray or ExtensionArray
4501 """
4502 self._ensure_valid_index(value)
4503  
4504 # We should never get here with DataFrame value
4505 if isinstance(value, Series):
4506 return _reindex_for_setitem(value, self.index)
4507  
4508 if is_list_like(value):
4509 com.require_length_match(value, self.index)
4510 return sanitize_array(value, self.index, copy=True, allow_2d=True)
4511  
4512 @property
4513 def _series(self):
4514 return {
4515 item: Series(
4516 self._mgr.iget(idx), index=self.index, name=item, fastpath=True
4517 )
4518 for idx, item in enumerate(self.columns)
4519 }
4520  
4521 def lookup(
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
4522 self, row_labels: Sequence[IndexLabel], col_labels: Sequence[IndexLabel]
4523 ) -> np.ndarray:
4524 """
4525 Label-based "fancy indexing" function for DataFrame.
4526 Given equal-length arrays of row and column labels, return an
4527 array of the values corresponding to each (row, col) pair.
4528  
4529 .. deprecated:: 1.2.0
4530 DataFrame.lookup is deprecated,
4531 use DataFrame.melt and DataFrame.loc instead.
4532 For further details see
4533 :ref:`Looking up values by index/column labels <indexing.lookup>`.
4534  
4535 Parameters
4536 ----------
4537 row_labels : sequence
4538 The row labels to use for lookup.
4539 col_labels : sequence
4540 The column labels to use for lookup.
4541  
4542 Returns
4543 -------
4544 numpy.ndarray
4545 The found values.
4546 """
4547 msg = (
4548 "The 'lookup' method is deprecated and will be"
4549 "removed in a future version."
4550 "You can use DataFrame.melt and DataFrame.loc"
4551 "as a substitute."
4552 )
4553 warnings.warn(msg, FutureWarning, stacklevel=2)
4554  
4555 n = len(row_labels)
4556 if n != len(col_labels):
4557 raise ValueError("Row labels must have same size as column labels")
4558 if not (self.index.is_unique and self.columns.is_unique):
4559 # GH#33041
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
4560 raise ValueError("DataFrame.lookup requires unique index and columns")
4561  
4562 thresh = 1000
4563 if not self._is_mixed_type or n > thresh:
4564 values = self.values
4565 ridx = self.index.get_indexer(row_labels)
4566 cidx = self.columns.get_indexer(col_labels)
4567 if (ridx == -1).any():
4568 raise KeyError("One or more row labels was not found")
4569 if (cidx == -1).any():
4570 raise KeyError("One or more column labels was not found")
4571 flat_index = ridx * len(self.columns) + cidx
4572 result = values.flat[flat_index]
4573 else:
4574 result = np.empty(n, dtype="O")
4575 for i, (r, c) in enumerate(zip(row_labels, col_labels)):
4576 result[i] = self._get_value(r, c)
4577  
4578 if is_object_dtype(result):
4579 result = lib.maybe_convert_objects(result)
4580  
4581 return result

4644 """

  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
4774 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(version=None, allowed_args=["self", "labels"])
4775 def drop(
4776 self,
4777 labels=None,
4778 axis: Axis = 0,
4779 index=None,
4780 columns=None,
4781 level: Level | None = None,
4782 inplace: bool = False,
4783 errors: str = "raise",
4784 ):
4785 """
4786 Drop specified labels from rows or columns.
4787  
4788 Remove rows or columns by specifying label names and corresponding
4789 axis, or by specifying directly index or column names. When using a
4790 multi-index, labels on different levels can be removed by specifying
4791 the level. See the `user guide <advanced.shown_levels>`
4792 for more information about the now unused levels.
4793  
4794 Parameters
4795 ----------
4796 labels : single label or list-like
4797 Index or column labels to drop.
4798 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
4799 Whether to drop labels from the index (0 or 'index') or
4800 columns (1 or 'columns').
4801 index : single label or list-like
4802 Alternative to specifying axis (``labels, axis=0``
4803 is equivalent to ``index=labels``).
4804 columns : single label or list-like
4805 Alternative to specifying axis (``labels, axis=1``
4806 is equivalent to ``columns=labels``).
4807 level : int or level name, optional
4808 For MultiIndex, level from which the labels will be removed.
4809 inplace : bool, default False
4810 If False, return a copy. Otherwise, do operation
4811 inplace and return None.
4812 errors : {'ignore', 'raise'}, default 'raise'
4813 If 'ignore', suppress error and only existing labels are
4814 dropped.
4815  
4816 Returns
4817 -------
4818 DataFrame or None
4819 DataFrame without the removed index or column labels or
4820 None if ``inplace=True``.
4821  
4822 Raises
4823 ------
4824 KeyError
4825 If any of the labels is not found in the selected axis.
4826  
4827 See Also
4828 --------
4829 DataFrame.loc : Label-location based indexer for selection by label.
4830 DataFrame.dropna : Return DataFrame with labels on given axis omitted
4831 where (all or any) data are missing.
4832 DataFrame.drop_duplicates : Return DataFrame with duplicate rows
4833 removed, optionally only considering certain columns.
4834 Series.drop : Return Series with specified index labels removed.
4835  
4836 Examples
4837 --------
4838 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(np.arange(12).reshape(3, 4),
4839 ... columns=['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'])
4840 >>> df
4841 A B C D
4842 0 0 1 2 3
4843 1 4 5 6 7
4844 2 8 9 10 11
4845  
4846 Drop columns
4847  
4848 >>> df.drop(['B', 'C'], axis=1)
4849 A D
4850 0 0 3
4851 1 4 7
4852 2 8 11
4853  
4854 >>> df.drop(columns=['B', 'C'])
4855 A D
4856 0 0 3
4857 1 4 7
4858 2 8 11
4859  
4860 Drop a row by index
4861  
4862 >>> df.drop([0, 1])
4863 A B C D
4864 2 8 9 10 11
4865  
4866 Drop columns and/or rows of MultiIndex DataFrame
4867  
4868 >>> midx = pd.MultiIndex(levels=[['lama', 'cow', 'falcon'],
4869 ... ['speed', 'weight', 'length']],
4870 ... codes=[[0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2],
4871 ... [0, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2]])
4872 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(index=midx, columns=['big', 'small'],
4873 ... data=[[45, 30], [200, 100], [1.5, 1], [30, 20],
4874 ... [250, 150], [1.5, 0.8], [320, 250],
4875 ... [1, 0.8], [0.3, 0.2]])
4876 >>> df
4877 big small
4878 lama speed 45.0 30.0
4879 weight 200.0 100.0
4880 length 1.5 1.0
4881 cow speed 30.0 20.0
4882 weight 250.0 150.0
4883 length 1.5 0.8
4884 falcon speed 320.0 250.0
4885 weight 1.0 0.8
4886 length 0.3 0.2
4887  
4888 >>> df.drop(index='cow', columns='small')
4889 big
4890 lama speed 45.0
4891 weight 200.0
4892 length 1.5
4893 falcon speed 320.0
4894 weight 1.0
4895 length 0.3
4896  
4897 >>> df.drop(index='length', level=1)
4898 big small
4899 lama speed 45.0 30.0
4900 weight 200.0 100.0
4901 cow speed 30.0 20.0
4902 weight 250.0 150.0
4903 falcon speed 320.0 250.0
4904 weight 1.0 0.8
4905 """
4906 return super().drop(
4907 labels=labels,
4908 axis=axis,
4909 index=index,
4910 columns=columns,
4911 level=level,
4912 inplace=inplace,
4913 errors=errors,
4914 )
4915  
4916 @rewrite_axis_style_signature(
4917 "mapper",
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
4918 [("copy", True), ("inplace", False), ("level", None), ("errors", "ignore")],
4919 )
4920 def rename(
4921 self,
4922 mapper: Renamer | None = None,
4923 *,
4924 index: Renamer | None = None,
4925 columns: Renamer | None = None,
4926 axis: Axis | None = None,
4927 copy: bool = True,
4928 inplace: bool = False,
4929 level: Level | None = None,
4930 errors: str = "ignore",
4931 ) -> DataFrame | None:
4932 """
4933 Alter axes labels.
4934  
4935 Function / dict values must be unique (1-to-1). Labels not contained in
4936 a dict / Series will be left as-is. Extra labels listed don't throw an
4937 error.
4938  
4939 See the :ref:`user guide <basics.rename>` for more.
4940  
4941 Parameters
4942 ----------
4943 mapper : dict-like or function
4944 Dict-like or function transformations to apply to
4945 that axis' values. Use either ``mapper`` and ``axis`` to
4946 specify the axis to target with ``mapper``, or ``index`` and
4947 ``columns``.
4948 index : dict-like or function
4949 Alternative to specifying axis (``mapper, axis=0``
4950 is equivalent to ``index=mapper``).
4951 columns : dict-like or function
4952 Alternative to specifying axis (``mapper, axis=1``
4953 is equivalent to ``columns=mapper``).
4954 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
4955 Axis to target with ``mapper``. Can be either the axis name
4956 ('index', 'columns') or number (0, 1). The default is 'index'.
4957 copy : bool, default True
4958 Also copy underlying data.
4959 inplace : bool, default False
4960 Whether to return a new DataFrame. If True then value of copy is
4961 ignored.
4962 level : int or level name, default None
4963 In case of a MultiIndex, only rename labels in the specified
4964 level.
4965 errors : {'ignore', 'raise'}, default 'ignore'
4966 If 'raise', raise a `KeyError` when a dict-like `mapper`, `index`,
4967 or `columns` contains labels that are not present in the Index
4968 being transformed.
4969 If 'ignore', existing keys will be renamed and extra keys will be
4970 ignored.
4971  
4972 Returns
4973 -------
4974 DataFrame or None
4975 DataFrame with the renamed axis labels or None if ``inplace=True``.
4976  
4977 Raises
4978 ------
4979 KeyError
4980 If any of the labels is not found in the selected axis and
4981 "errors='raise'".
4982  
4983 See Also
4984 --------
4985 DataFrame.rename_axis : Set the name of the axis.
4986  
4987 Examples
4988 --------
4989 ``DataFrame.rename`` supports two calling conventions
4990  
4991 * ``(index=index_mapper, columns=columns_mapper, ...)``
4992 * ``(mapper, axis={'index', 'columns'}, ...)``
4993  
4994 We *highly* recommend using keyword arguments to clarify your
4995 intent.
4996  
4997 Rename columns using a mapping:
4998  
4999 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"A": [1, 2, 3], "B": [4, 5, 6]})
5000 >>> df.rename(columns={"A": "a", "B": "c"})
5001 a c
5002 0 1 4
5003 1 2 5
5004 2 3 6
5005  
5006 Rename index using a mapping:
5007  
5008 >>> df.rename(index={0: "x", 1: "y", 2: "z"})
5009 A B
5010 x 1 4
5011 y 2 5
5012 z 3 6
5013  
5014 Cast index labels to a different type:
5015  
5016 >>> df.index
5017 RangeIndex(start=0, stop=3, step=1)
5018 >>> df.rename(index=str).index
5019 Index(['0', '1', '2'], dtype='object')
5020  
5021 >>> df.rename(columns={"A": "a", "B": "b", "C": "c"}, errors="raise")
5022 Traceback (most recent call last):
5023 KeyError: ['C'] not found in axis
5024  
5025 Using axis-style parameters:
5026  
5027 >>> df.rename(str.lower, axis='columns')
5028 a b
5029 0 1 4
5030 1 2 5
5031 2 3 6
5032  
5033 >>> df.rename({1: 2, 2: 4}, axis='index')
5034 A B
5035 0 1 4
5036 2 2 5
5037 4 3 6
5038 """
5039 return super().rename(
5040 mapper=mapper,
5041 index=index,
5042 columns=columns,
5043 axis=axis,
5044 copy=copy,
5045 inplace=inplace,
5046 level=level,
5047 errors=errors,
5048 )
5049

5185 def pop(self, item: Hashable) -> Series:
5186 """
5187 Return item and drop from frame. Raise KeyError if not found.
5188  
5189 Parameters
5190 ----------
5191 item : label
5192 Label of column to be popped.
5193  
5194 Returns
5195 -------
5196 Series
5197  
5198 Examples
5199 --------
5200 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([('falcon', 'bird', 389.0),
5201 ... ('parrot', 'bird', 24.0),
5202 ... ('lion', 'mammal', 80.5),
5203 ... ('monkey', 'mammal', np.nan)],
5204 ... columns=('name', 'class', 'max_speed'))
5205 >>> df
5206 name class max_speed
5207 0 falcon bird 389.0
5208 1 parrot bird 24.0
5209 2 lion mammal 80.5
5210 3 monkey mammal NaN
5211  
5212 >>> df.pop('class')
5213 0 bird
5214 1 bird
5215 2 mammal
5216 3 mammal
5217 Name: class, dtype: object
5218  
5219 >>> df
5220 name max_speed
5221 0 falcon 389.0
5222 1 parrot 24.0
5223 2 lion 80.5
5224 3 monkey NaN
5225 """
5226 return super().pop(item=item)

5246  
5247 def _replace_columnwise(
5248 self, mapping: dict[Hashable, tuple[Any, Any]], inplace: bool, regex
5249 ):
5250 """
5251 Dispatch to Series.replace column-wise.
5252  
5253  
5254 Parameters
5255 ----------
5256 mapping : dict
5257 of the form {col: (target, value)}
5258 inplace : bool
5259 regex : bool or same types as `to_replace` in DataFrame.replace
5260  
5261 Returns
5262 -------
5263 DataFrame or None
5264 """
5265 # Operate column-wise
5266 res = self if inplace else self.copy()
5267 ax = self.columns
5268  
5269 for i in range(len(ax)):
5270 if ax[i] in mapping:
5271 ser = self.iloc[:, i]
5272  
5273 target, value = mapping[ax[i]]
5274 newobj = ser.replace(target, value, regex=regex)
5275  
5276 res.iloc[:, i] = newobj
5277  
5278 if inplace:
5279 return
5280 return res.__finalize__(self)
5281  
5282 @doc(NDFrame.shift, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])

5286 freq: Frequency | None = None,
5287 axis: Axis = 0,
5288 fill_value=lib.no_default,
5289 ) -> DataFrame:
5290 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
5291  
5292 ncols = len(self.columns)

5295

5296 # Use a column that we know is valid for our column's dtype GH#38434
5297 label = self.columns[0]
5298

5303 # Define filler inside loop so we get a copy
5304 filler = self.iloc[:, 0].shift(len(self))

5322 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(version=None, allowed_args=["self", "keys"])
5323 def set_index(
5324 self,
5325 keys,
5326 drop: bool = True,
5327 append: bool = False,
5328 inplace: bool = False,
5329 verify_integrity: bool = False,
5330 ):
5331 """
5332 Set the DataFrame index using existing columns.
5333  
5334 Set the DataFrame index (row labels) using one or more existing
5335 columns or arrays (of the correct length). The index can replace the
5336 existing index or expand on it.
5337  
5338 Parameters
5339 ----------
5340 keys : label or array-like or list of labels/arrays
5341 This parameter can be either a single column key, a single array of
5342 the same length as the calling DataFrame, or a list containing an
5343 arbitrary combination of column keys and arrays. Here, "array"
5344 encompasses :class:`Series`, :class:`Index`, ``np.ndarray``, and
5345 instances of :class:`~collections.abc.Iterator`.
5346 drop : bool, default True
5347 Delete columns to be used as the new index.
5348 append : bool, default False
5349 Whether to append columns to existing index.
5350 inplace : bool, default False
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
5351 If True, modifies the DataFrame in place (do not create a new object).
5352 verify_integrity : bool, default False
5353 Check the new index for duplicates. Otherwise defer the check until
5354 necessary. Setting to False will improve the performance of this
5355 method.
5356  
5357 Returns
5358 -------
5359 DataFrame or None
5360 Changed row labels or None if ``inplace=True``.
5361  
5362 See Also
5363 --------
5364 DataFrame.reset_index : Opposite of set_index.
5365 DataFrame.reindex : Change to new indices or expand indices.
5366 DataFrame.reindex_like : Change to same indices as other DataFrame.
5367  
5368 Examples
5369 --------
5370 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'month': [1, 4, 7, 10],
5371 ... 'year': [2012, 2014, 2013, 2014],
5372 ... 'sale': [55, 40, 84, 31]})
5373 >>> df
5374 month year sale
5375 0 1 2012 55
5376 1 4 2014 40
5377 2 7 2013 84
5378 3 10 2014 31
5379  
5380 Set the index to become the 'month' column:
5381  
5382 >>> df.set_index('month')
5383 year sale
5384 month
5385 1 2012 55
5386 4 2014 40
5387 7 2013 84
5388 10 2014 31
5389  
5390 Create a MultiIndex using columns 'year' and 'month':
5391  
5392 >>> df.set_index(['year', 'month'])
5393 sale
5394 year month
5395 2012 1 55
5396 2014 4 40
5397 2013 7 84
5398 2014 10 31
5399  
5400 Create a MultiIndex using an Index and a column:
5401  
5402 >>> df.set_index([pd.Index([1, 2, 3, 4]), 'year'])
5403 month sale
5404 year
5405 1 2012 1 55
5406 2 2014 4 40
5407 3 2013 7 84
5408 4 2014 10 31
5409  
5410 Create a MultiIndex using two Series:
5411  
5412 >>> s = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4])
5413 >>> df.set_index([s, s**2])
5414 month year sale
5415 1 1 1 2012 55
5416 2 4 4 2014 40
5417 3 9 7 2013 84
5418 4 16 10 2014 31
5419 """
5420 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
5421 self._check_inplace_and_allows_duplicate_labels(inplace)
5422 if not isinstance(keys, list):
5423 keys = [keys]
5424  
5425 err_msg = (
5426 'The parameter "keys" may be a column key, one-dimensional '
5427 "array, or a list containing only valid column keys and "
5428 "one-dimensional arrays."
5429 )
5430  
5431 missing: list[Hashable] = []
5432 for col in keys:
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
5433 if isinstance(col, (Index, Series, np.ndarray, list, abc.Iterator)):
5434 # arrays are fine as long as they are one-dimensional
5435 # iterators get converted to list below
5436 if getattr(col, "ndim", 1) != 1:
5437 raise ValueError(err_msg)
5438 else:
5439 # everything else gets tried as a key; see GH 24969
5440 try:
5441 found = col in self.columns
5442 except TypeError as err:
5443 raise TypeError(
5444 f"{err_msg}. Received column of type {type(col)}"
5445 ) from err
5446 else:
5447 if not found:
5448 missing.append(col)
5449  
5450 if missing:
5451 raise KeyError(f"None of {missing} are in the columns")
5452  
5453 if inplace:
5454 frame = self
5455 else:
5456 frame = self.copy()
5457  
5458 arrays = []
5459 names: list[Hashable] = []
5460 if append:
5461 names = list(self.index.names)
5462 if isinstance(self.index, MultiIndex):
5463 for i in range(self.index.nlevels):
5464 arrays.append(self.index._get_level_values(i))
5465 else:
5466 arrays.append(self.index)
5467  
5468 to_remove: list[Hashable] = []
5469 for col in keys:
5470 if isinstance(col, MultiIndex):
5471 for n in range(col.nlevels):
5472 arrays.append(col._get_level_values(n))
5473 names.extend(col.names)
5474 elif isinstance(col, (Index, Series)):
5475 # if Index then not MultiIndex (treated above)
5476  
5477 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
5478 # "Union[Index, Series]"; expected "Index"
5479 arrays.append(col) # type:ignore[arg-type]
5480 names.append(col.name)
5481 elif isinstance(col, (list, np.ndarray)):
5482 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
5483 # "Union[List[Any], ndarray]"; expected "Index"
5484 arrays.append(col) # type: ignore[arg-type]
5485 names.append(None)
5486 elif isinstance(col, abc.Iterator):
5487 # error: Argument 1 to "append" of "list" has incompatible type
5488 # "List[Any]"; expected "Index"
5489 arrays.append(list(col)) # type: ignore[arg-type]
5490 names.append(None)
5491 # from here, col can only be a column label
5492 else:
5493 arrays.append(frame[col]._values)
5494 names.append(col)
5495 if drop:
5496 to_remove.append(col)
5497  
5498 if len(arrays[-1]) != len(self):
5499 # check newest element against length of calling frame, since
5500 # ensure_index_from_sequences would not raise for append=False.
5501 raise ValueError(
5502 f"Length mismatch: Expected {len(self)} rows, "
5503 f"received array of length {len(arrays[-1])}"
5504 )
5505  
5506 index = ensure_index_from_sequences(arrays, names)
5507  
5508 if verify_integrity and not index.is_unique:
5509 duplicates = index[index.duplicated()].unique()
5510 raise ValueError(f"Index has duplicate keys: {duplicates}")
5511  
5512 # use set to handle duplicate column names gracefully in case of drop
5513 for c in set(to_remove):
5514 del frame[c]
5515  
5516 # clear up memory usage
5517 index._cleanup()
5518  
5519 frame.index = index
5520  
5521 if not inplace:
5522 return frame
5523
