  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
5589 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(version=None, allowed_args=["self", "level"])
5590 def reset_index(
5591 self,
5592 level: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
5593 drop: bool = False,
5594 inplace: bool = False,
5595 col_level: Hashable = 0,
5596 col_fill: Hashable = "",
5597 ) -> DataFrame | None:
5598 """
5599 Reset the index, or a level of it.
5600  
5601 Reset the index of the DataFrame, and use the default one instead.
5602 If the DataFrame has a MultiIndex, this method can remove one or more
5603 levels.
5604  
5605 Parameters
5606 ----------
5607 level : int, str, tuple, or list, default None
5608 Only remove the given levels from the index. Removes all levels by
5609 default.
5610 drop : bool, default False
5611 Do not try to insert index into dataframe columns. This resets
5612 the index to the default integer index.
5613 inplace : bool, default False
5614 Modify the DataFrame in place (do not create a new object).
5615 col_level : int or str, default 0
5616 If the columns have multiple levels, determines which level the
5617 labels are inserted into. By default it is inserted into the first
5618 level.
5619 col_fill : object, default ''
5620 If the columns have multiple levels, determines how the other
5621 levels are named. If None then the index name is repeated.
5622  
5623 Returns
5624 -------
5625 DataFrame or None
5626 DataFrame with the new index or None if ``inplace=True``.
5627  
5628 See Also
5629 --------
5630 DataFrame.set_index : Opposite of reset_index.
5631 DataFrame.reindex : Change to new indices or expand indices.
5632 DataFrame.reindex_like : Change to same indices as other DataFrame.
5633  
5634 Examples
5635 --------
5636 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([('bird', 389.0),
5637 ... ('bird', 24.0),
5638 ... ('mammal', 80.5),
5639 ... ('mammal', np.nan)],
5640 ... index=['falcon', 'parrot', 'lion', 'monkey'],
5641 ... columns=('class', 'max_speed'))
5642 >>> df
5643 class max_speed
5644 falcon bird 389.0
5645 parrot bird 24.0
5646 lion mammal 80.5
5647 monkey mammal NaN
5648  
5649 When we reset the index, the old index is added as a column, and a
5650 new sequential index is used:
5651  
5652 >>> df.reset_index()
5653 index class max_speed
5654 0 falcon bird 389.0
5655 1 parrot bird 24.0
5656 2 lion mammal 80.5
5657 3 monkey mammal NaN
5658  
5659 We can use the `drop` parameter to avoid the old index being added as
5660 a column:
5661  
5662 >>> df.reset_index(drop=True)
5663 class max_speed
5664 0 bird 389.0
5665 1 bird 24.0
5666 2 mammal 80.5
5667 3 mammal NaN
5668  
5669 You can also use `reset_index` with `MultiIndex`.
5670  
5671 >>> index = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([('bird', 'falcon'),
5672 ... ('bird', 'parrot'),
5673 ... ('mammal', 'lion'),
5674 ... ('mammal', 'monkey')],
5675 ... names=['class', 'name'])
5676 >>> columns = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([('speed', 'max'),
5677 ... ('species', 'type')])
5678 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([(389.0, 'fly'),
5679 ... ( 24.0, 'fly'),
5680 ... ( 80.5, 'run'),
5681 ... (np.nan, 'jump')],
5682 ... index=index,
5683 ... columns=columns)
5684 >>> df
5685 speed species
5686 max type
5687 class name
5688 bird falcon 389.0 fly
5689 parrot 24.0 fly
5690 mammal lion 80.5 run
5691 monkey NaN jump
5692  
5693 If the index has multiple levels, we can reset a subset of them:
5694  
5695 >>> df.reset_index(level='class')
5696 class speed species
5697 max type
5698 name
5699 falcon bird 389.0 fly
5700 parrot bird 24.0 fly
5701 lion mammal 80.5 run
5702 monkey mammal NaN jump
5703  
5704 If we are not dropping the index, by default, it is placed in the top
5705 level. We can place it in another level:
5706  
5707 >>> df.reset_index(level='class', col_level=1)
5708 speed species
5709 class max type
5710 name
5711 falcon bird 389.0 fly
5712 parrot bird 24.0 fly
5713 lion mammal 80.5 run
5714 monkey mammal NaN jump
5715  
5716 When the index is inserted under another level, we can specify under
5717 which one with the parameter `col_fill`:
5718  
5719 >>> df.reset_index(level='class', col_level=1, col_fill='species')
5720 species speed species
5721 class max type
5722 name
5723 falcon bird 389.0 fly
5724 parrot bird 24.0 fly
5725 lion mammal 80.5 run
5726 monkey mammal NaN jump
5727  
5728 If we specify a nonexistent level for `col_fill`, it is created:
5729  
5730 >>> df.reset_index(level='class', col_level=1, col_fill='genus')
5731 genus speed species
5732 class max type
5733 name
5734 falcon bird 389.0 fly
5735 parrot bird 24.0 fly
5736 lion mammal 80.5 run
5737 monkey mammal NaN jump
5738 """
5739 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
5740 self._check_inplace_and_allows_duplicate_labels(inplace)
5741 if inplace:
5742 new_obj = self
5743 else:
5744 new_obj = self.copy()
5745  
5746 new_index = ibase.default_index(len(new_obj))
5747 if level is not None:
5748 if not isinstance(level, (tuple, list)):
5749 level = [level]
5750 level = [self.index._get_level_number(lev) for lev in level]
5751 if len(level) < self.index.nlevels:
5752 new_index = self.index.droplevel(level)
5753  
5754 if not drop:
5755 to_insert: Iterable[tuple[Any, Any | None]]
5756 if isinstance(self.index, MultiIndex):
5757 names = [
5758 (n if n is not None else f"level_{i}")
5759 for i, n in enumerate(self.index.names)
5760 ]
5761 to_insert = zip(self.index.levels, self.index.codes)
5762 else:
5763 default = "index" if "index" not in self else "level_0"
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
5764 names = [default] if self.index.name is None else [self.index.name]
5765 to_insert = ((self.index, None),)
5766  
5767 multi_col = isinstance(self.columns, MultiIndex)
5768 for i, (lev, lab) in reversed(list(enumerate(to_insert))):
5769 if level is not None and i not in level:
5770 continue
5771 name = names[i]
5772 if multi_col:
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
5773 col_name = list(name) if isinstance(name, tuple) else [name]
5774 if col_fill is None:
5775 if len(col_name) not in (1, self.columns.nlevels):
5776 raise ValueError(
5777 "col_fill=None is incompatible "
5778 f"with incomplete column name {name}"
5779 )
5780 col_fill = col_name[0]
5781  
5782 lev_num = self.columns._get_level_number(col_level)
5783 name_lst = [col_fill] * lev_num + col_name
5784 missing = self.columns.nlevels - len(name_lst)
5785 name_lst += [col_fill] * missing
5786 name = tuple(name_lst)
5787  
5788 # to ndarray and maybe infer different dtype
5789 level_values = lev._values
5790 if level_values.dtype == np.object_:
5791 level_values = lib.maybe_convert_objects(level_values)
5792  
5793 if lab is not None:
5794 # if we have the codes, extract the values with a mask
5795 level_values = algorithms.take(
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
5796 level_values, lab, allow_fill=True, fill_value=lev._na_value
5797 )
5798  
5799 new_obj.insert(0, name, level_values)
5800  
5801 new_obj.index = new_index
5802 if not inplace:
5803 return new_obj
5804  
5805 return None
5806  
5807 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
5808 # Reindex-based selection methods
5809  
5810 @doc(NDFrame.isna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
5811 def isna(self) -> DataFrame:
5812 result = self._constructor(self._mgr.isna(func=isna))
5813 return result.__finalize__(self, method="isna")
5814  
5815 @doc(NDFrame.isna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
5816 def isnull(self) -> DataFrame:
5817 return self.isna()
5818  
5819 @doc(NDFrame.notna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
5820 def notna(self) -> DataFrame:
5821 return ~self.isna()
5822  
5823 @doc(NDFrame.notna, klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"])
5824 def notnull(self) -> DataFrame:
5825 return ~self.isna()
5826  
5827 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(version=None, allowed_args=["self"])
5828 def dropna(
5829 self,
5830 axis: Axis = 0,
5831 how: str = "any",
5832 thresh=None,
5833 subset=None,
5834 inplace: bool = False,
5835 ):
5836 """
5837 Remove missing values.
5838  
5839 See the :ref:`User Guide <missing_data>` for more on which values are
5840 considered missing, and how to work with missing data.
5841  
5842 Parameters
5843 ----------
5844 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
5845 Determine if rows or columns which contain missing values are
5846 removed.
5847  
5848 * 0, or 'index' : Drop rows which contain missing values.
5849 * 1, or 'columns' : Drop columns which contain missing value.
5850  
5851 .. versionchanged:: 1.0.0
5852  
5853 Pass tuple or list to drop on multiple axes.
5854 Only a single axis is allowed.
5855  
5856 how : {'any', 'all'}, default 'any'
5857 Determine if row or column is removed from DataFrame, when we have
5858 at least one NA or all NA.
5859  
5860 * 'any' : If any NA values are present, drop that row or column.
5861 * 'all' : If all values are NA, drop that row or column.
5862  
5863 thresh : int, optional
5864 Require that many non-NA values.
5865 subset : array-like, optional
5866 Labels along other axis to consider, e.g. if you are dropping rows
5867 these would be a list of columns to include.
5868 inplace : bool, default False
5869 If True, do operation inplace and return None.
5870  
5871 Returns
5872 -------
5873 DataFrame or None
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
5874 DataFrame with NA entries dropped from it or None if ``inplace=True``.
5875  
5876 See Also
5877 --------
5878 DataFrame.isna: Indicate missing values.
5879 DataFrame.notna : Indicate existing (non-missing) values.
5880 DataFrame.fillna : Replace missing values.
5881 Series.dropna : Drop missing values.
5882 Index.dropna : Drop missing indices.
5883  
5884 Examples
5885 --------
5886 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"name": ['Alfred', 'Batman', 'Catwoman'],
5887 ... "toy": [np.nan, 'Batmobile', 'Bullwhip'],
5888 ... "born": [pd.NaT, pd.Timestamp("1940-04-25"),
5889 ... pd.NaT]})
5890 >>> df
5891 name toy born
5892 0 Alfred NaN NaT
5893 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
5894 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
5895  
5896 Drop the rows where at least one element is missing.
5897  
5898 >>> df.dropna()
5899 name toy born
5900 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
5901  
5902 Drop the columns where at least one element is missing.
5903  
5904 >>> df.dropna(axis='columns')
5905 name
5906 0 Alfred
5907 1 Batman
5908 2 Catwoman
5909  
5910 Drop the rows where all elements are missing.
5911  
5912 >>> df.dropna(how='all')
5913 name toy born
5914 0 Alfred NaN NaT
5915 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
5916 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
5917  
5918 Keep only the rows with at least 2 non-NA values.
5919  
5920 >>> df.dropna(thresh=2)
5921 name toy born
5922 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
5923 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
5924  
5925 Define in which columns to look for missing values.
5926  
5927 >>> df.dropna(subset=['name', 'toy'])
5928 name toy born
5929 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
5930 2 Catwoman Bullwhip NaT
5931  
5932 Keep the DataFrame with valid entries in the same variable.
5933  
5934 >>> df.dropna(inplace=True)
5935 >>> df
5936 name toy born
5937 1 Batman Batmobile 1940-04-25
5938 """
5939 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
5940 if isinstance(axis, (tuple, list)):
5941 # GH20987
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
5942 raise TypeError("supplying multiple axes to axis is no longer supported.")
5943  
5944 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
5945 agg_axis = 1 - axis
5946  
5947 agg_obj = self
5948 if subset is not None:
5949 ax = self._get_axis(agg_axis)
5950 indices = ax.get_indexer_for(subset)
5951 check = indices == -1
5952 if check.any():
5953 raise KeyError(list(np.compress(check, subset)))
5954 agg_obj = self.take(indices, axis=agg_axis)
5955  
5956 count = agg_obj.count(axis=agg_axis)
5957  
5958 if thresh is not None:
5959 mask = count >= thresh
5960 elif how == "any":
5961 mask = count == len(agg_obj._get_axis(agg_axis))
5962 elif how == "all":
5963 mask = count > 0
5964 else:
5965 if how is not None:
5966 raise ValueError(f"invalid how option: {how}")
5967 else:
5968 raise TypeError("must specify how or thresh")
5969  
5970 result = self.loc(axis=axis)[mask]
5971  
5972 if inplace:
5973 self._update_inplace(result)
5974 else:
5975 return result
5976  
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
5977 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(version=None, allowed_args=["self", "subset"])
5978 def drop_duplicates(
5979 self,
5980 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
5981 keep: Literal["first"] | Literal["last"] | Literal[False] = "first",
5982 inplace: bool = False,
5983 ignore_index: bool = False,
5984 ) -> DataFrame | None:
5985 """
5986 Return DataFrame with duplicate rows removed.
5987  
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
5988 Considering certain columns is optional. Indexes, including time indexes
5989 are ignored.
5990  
5991 Parameters
5992 ----------
5993 subset : column label or sequence of labels, optional
5994 Only consider certain columns for identifying duplicates, by
5995 default use all of the columns.
5996 keep : {'first', 'last', False}, default 'first'
5997 Determines which duplicates (if any) to keep.
5998 - ``first`` : Drop duplicates except for the first occurrence.
5999 - ``last`` : Drop duplicates except for the last occurrence.
6000 - False : Drop all duplicates.
6001 inplace : bool, default False
6002 Whether to drop duplicates in place or to return a copy.
6003 ignore_index : bool, default False
6004 If True, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, …, n - 1.
6005  
6006 .. versionadded:: 1.0.0
6007  
6008 Returns
6009 -------
6010 DataFrame or None
6011 DataFrame with duplicates removed or None if ``inplace=True``.
6012  
6013 See Also
6014 --------
6015 DataFrame.value_counts: Count unique combinations of columns.
6016  
6017 Examples
6018 --------
6019 Consider dataset containing ramen rating.
6020  
6021 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
6022 ... 'brand': ['Yum Yum', 'Yum Yum', 'Indomie', 'Indomie', 'Indomie'],
6023 ... 'style': ['cup', 'cup', 'cup', 'pack', 'pack'],
6024 ... 'rating': [4, 4, 3.5, 15, 5]
6025 ... })
6026 >>> df
6027 brand style rating
6028 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6029 1 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6030 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6031 3 Indomie pack 15.0
6032 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6033  
6034 By default, it removes duplicate rows based on all columns.
6035  
6036 >>> df.drop_duplicates()
6037 brand style rating
6038 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6039 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6040 3 Indomie pack 15.0
6041 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6042  
6043 To remove duplicates on specific column(s), use ``subset``.
6044  
6045 >>> df.drop_duplicates(subset=['brand'])
6046 brand style rating
6047 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6048 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6049  
6050 To remove duplicates and keep last occurrences, use ``keep``.
6051  
6052 >>> df.drop_duplicates(subset=['brand', 'style'], keep='last')
6053 brand style rating
6054 1 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6055 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6056 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6057 """
6058 if self.empty:
6059 return self.copy()
6060  
6061 inplace = validate_bool_kwarg(inplace, "inplace")
6062 ignore_index = validate_bool_kwarg(ignore_index, "ignore_index")
6063 duplicated = self.duplicated(subset, keep=keep)
6064  
6065 result = self[-duplicated]
6066 if ignore_index:
6067 result.index = ibase.default_index(len(result))
6068  
6069 if inplace:
6070 self._update_inplace(result)
6071 return None
6072 else:
6073 return result
6074  
6075 def duplicated(
6076 self,
6077 subset: Hashable | Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6078 keep: Literal["first"] | Literal["last"] | Literal[False] = "first",
6079 ) -> Series:
6080 """
6081 Return boolean Series denoting duplicate rows.
6082  
6083 Considering certain columns is optional.
6084  
6085 Parameters
6086 ----------
6087 subset : column label or sequence of labels, optional
6088 Only consider certain columns for identifying duplicates, by
6089 default use all of the columns.
6090 keep : {'first', 'last', False}, default 'first'
6091 Determines which duplicates (if any) to mark.
6092  
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
6093 - ``first`` : Mark duplicates as ``True`` except for the first occurrence.
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
6094 - ``last`` : Mark duplicates as ``True`` except for the last occurrence.
6095 - False : Mark all duplicates as ``True``.
6096  
6097 Returns
6098 -------
6099 Series
6100 Boolean series for each duplicated rows.
6101  
6102 See Also
6103 --------
6104 Index.duplicated : Equivalent method on index.
6105 Series.duplicated : Equivalent method on Series.
6106 Series.drop_duplicates : Remove duplicate values from Series.
6107 DataFrame.drop_duplicates : Remove duplicate values from DataFrame.
6108  
6109 Examples
6110 --------
6111 Consider dataset containing ramen rating.
6112  
6113 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
6114 ... 'brand': ['Yum Yum', 'Yum Yum', 'Indomie', 'Indomie', 'Indomie'],
6115 ... 'style': ['cup', 'cup', 'cup', 'pack', 'pack'],
6116 ... 'rating': [4, 4, 3.5, 15, 5]
6117 ... })
6118 >>> df
6119 brand style rating
6120 0 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6121 1 Yum Yum cup 4.0
6122 2 Indomie cup 3.5
6123 3 Indomie pack 15.0
6124 4 Indomie pack 5.0
6125  
6126 By default, for each set of duplicated values, the first occurrence
6127 is set on False and all others on True.
6128  
6129 >>> df.duplicated()
6130 0 False
6131 1 True
6132 2 False
6133 3 False
6134 4 False
6135 dtype: bool
6136  
6137 By using 'last', the last occurrence of each set of duplicated values
6138 is set on False and all others on True.
6139  
6140 >>> df.duplicated(keep='last')
6141 0 True
6142 1 False
6143 2 False
6144 3 False
6145 4 False
6146 dtype: bool
6147  
6148 By setting ``keep`` on False, all duplicates are True.
6149  
6150 >>> df.duplicated(keep=False)
6151 0 True
6152 1 True
6153 2 False
6154 3 False
6155 4 False
6156 dtype: bool
6157  
6158 To find duplicates on specific column(s), use ``subset``.
6159  
6160 >>> df.duplicated(subset=['brand'])
6161 0 False
6162 1 True
6163 2 False
6164 3 True
6165 4 True
6166 dtype: bool
6167 """
6168  
6169 if self.empty:
6170 return self._constructor_sliced(dtype=bool)
6171  
6172 def f(vals) -> tuple[np.ndarray, int]:
6173 labels, shape = algorithms.factorize(vals, size_hint=len(self))
6174 return labels.astype("i8", copy=False), len(shape)
6175  
6176 if subset is None:
6177 # Incompatible types in assignment
6178 # (expression has type "Index", variable has type "Sequence[Any]")
6179 # (pending on https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/28770)
6180 subset = self.columns # type: ignore[assignment]
6181 elif (
6182 not np.iterable(subset)
6183 or isinstance(subset, str)
6184 or isinstance(subset, tuple)
6185 and subset in self.columns
6186 ):
6187 subset = (subset,)
6188  
6189 # needed for mypy since can't narrow types using np.iterable
6190 subset = cast(Iterable, subset)
6191  
6192 # Verify all columns in subset exist in the queried dataframe
6193 # Otherwise, raise a KeyError, same as if you try to __getitem__ with a
6194 # key that doesn't exist.
6195 diff = Index(subset).difference(self.columns)
6196 if not diff.empty:
6197 raise KeyError(diff)
6198  
6199 vals = (col.values for name, col in self.items() if name in subset)
6200 labels, shape = map(list, zip(*map(f, vals)))
6201  
6202 ids = get_group_index(
6203 labels,
6204 # error: Argument 1 to "tuple" has incompatible type "List[_T]";
6205 # expected "Iterable[int]"
6206 tuple(shape), # type: ignore[arg-type]
6207 sort=False,
6208 xnull=False,
6209 )
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
6210 result = self._constructor_sliced(duplicated(ids, keep), index=self.index)
6211 return result.__finalize__(self, method="duplicated")
6212  
6213 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
6214 # Sorting
6215 # TODO: Just move the sort_values doc here.

6291 @deprecate_nonkeyword_arguments(version=None, allowed_args=["self"])
6292 def sort_index(
6293 self,
6294 axis: Axis = 0,
6295 level: Level | None = None,
6296 ascending: bool | int | Sequence[bool | int] = True,
6297 inplace: bool = False,
6298 kind: str = "quicksort",
6299 na_position: str = "last",
6300 sort_remaining: bool = True,
6301 ignore_index: bool = False,
6302 key: IndexKeyFunc = None,
6303 ):
6304 """
6305 Sort object by labels (along an axis).
6306  
6307 Returns a new DataFrame sorted by label if `inplace` argument is
6308 ``False``, otherwise updates the original DataFrame and returns None.
6309  
6310 Parameters
6311 ----------
6312 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
6313 The axis along which to sort. The value 0 identifies the rows,
6314 and 1 identifies the columns.
6315 level : int or level name or list of ints or list of level names
6316 If not None, sort on values in specified index level(s).
6317 ascending : bool or list-like of bools, default True
6318 Sort ascending vs. descending. When the index is a MultiIndex the
6319 sort direction can be controlled for each level individually.
6320 inplace : bool, default False
6321 If True, perform operation in-place.
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
6322 kind : {'quicksort', 'mergesort', 'heapsort', 'stable'}, default 'quicksort'
6323 Choice of sorting algorithm. See also :func:`numpy.sort` for more
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
6324 information. `mergesort` and `stable` are the only stable algorithms. For
6325 DataFrames, this option is only applied when sorting on a single
6326 column or label.
6327 na_position : {'first', 'last'}, default 'last'
6328 Puts NaNs at the beginning if `first`; `last` puts NaNs at the end.
6329 Not implemented for MultiIndex.
6330 sort_remaining : bool, default True
6331 If True and sorting by level and index is multilevel, sort by other
6332 levels too (in order) after sorting by specified level.
6333 ignore_index : bool, default False
6334 If True, the resulting axis will be labeled 0, 1, …, n - 1.
6335  
6336 .. versionadded:: 1.0.0
6337  
6338 key : callable, optional
6339 If not None, apply the key function to the index values
6340 before sorting. This is similar to the `key` argument in the
6341 builtin :meth:`sorted` function, with the notable difference that
6342 this `key` function should be *vectorized*. It should expect an
6343 ``Index`` and return an ``Index`` of the same shape. For MultiIndex
6344 inputs, the key is applied *per level*.
6345  
6346 .. versionadded:: 1.1.0
6347  
6348 Returns
6349 -------
6350 DataFrame or None
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
6351 The original DataFrame sorted by the labels or None if ``inplace=True``.
6352  
6353 See Also
6354 --------
6355 Series.sort_index : Sort Series by the index.
6356 DataFrame.sort_values : Sort DataFrame by the value.
6357 Series.sort_values : Sort Series by the value.
6358  
6359 Examples
6360 --------
6361 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], index=[100, 29, 234, 1, 150],
6362 ... columns=['A'])
6363 >>> df.sort_index()
6364 A
6365 1 4
6366 29 2
6367 100 1
6368 150 5
6369 234 3
6370  
6371 By default, it sorts in ascending order, to sort in descending order,
6372 use ``ascending=False``
6373  
6374 >>> df.sort_index(ascending=False)
6375 A
6376 234 3
6377 150 5
6378 100 1
6379 29 2
6380 1 4
6381  
6382 A key function can be specified which is applied to the index before
6383 sorting. For a ``MultiIndex`` this is applied to each level separately.
6384  
6385 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, 3, 4]}, index=['A', 'b', 'C', 'd'])
6386 >>> df.sort_index(key=lambda x: x.str.lower())
6387 a
6388 A 1
6389 b 2
6390 C 3
6391 d 4
6392 """
6393 return super().sort_index(
6394 axis,
6395 level,
6396 ascending,
6397 inplace,
6398 kind,
6399 na_position,
6400 sort_remaining,
6401 ignore_index,
6402 key,
6403 )
6404  
6405 def value_counts(
6406 self,
6407 subset: Sequence[Hashable] | None = None,
6408 normalize: bool = False,
6409 sort: bool = True,
6410 ascending: bool = False,
6411 dropna: bool = True,
6412 ):
6413 """
6414 Return a Series containing counts of unique rows in the DataFrame.
6415  
6416 .. versionadded:: 1.1.0
6417  
6418 Parameters
6419 ----------
6420 subset : list-like, optional
6421 Columns to use when counting unique combinations.
6422 normalize : bool, default False
6423 Return proportions rather than frequencies.
6424 sort : bool, default True
6425 Sort by frequencies.
6426 ascending : bool, default False
6427 Sort in ascending order.
6428 dropna : bool, default True
6429 Don’t include counts of rows that contain NA values.
6430  
6431 .. versionadded:: 1.3.0
6432  
6433 Returns
6434 -------
6435 Series
6436  
6437 See Also
6438 --------
6439 Series.value_counts: Equivalent method on Series.
6440  
6441 Notes
6442 -----
6443 The returned Series will have a MultiIndex with one level per input
6444 column. By default, rows that contain any NA values are omitted from
6445 the result. By default, the resulting Series will be in descending
6446 order so that the first element is the most frequently-occurring row.
6447  
6448 Examples
6449 --------
6450 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'num_legs': [2, 4, 4, 6],
6451 ... 'num_wings': [2, 0, 0, 0]},
6452 ... index=['falcon', 'dog', 'cat', 'ant'])
6453 >>> df
6454 num_legs num_wings
6455 falcon 2 2
6456 dog 4 0
6457 cat 4 0
6458 ant 6 0
6459  
6460 >>> df.value_counts()
6461 num_legs num_wings
6462 4 0 2
6463 2 2 1
6464 6 0 1
6465 dtype: int64
6466  
6467 >>> df.value_counts(sort=False)
6468 num_legs num_wings
6469 2 2 1
6470 4 0 2
6471 6 0 1
6472 dtype: int64
6473  
6474 >>> df.value_counts(ascending=True)
6475 num_legs num_wings
6476 2 2 1
6477 6 0 1
6478 4 0 2
6479 dtype: int64
6480  
6481 >>> df.value_counts(normalize=True)
6482 num_legs num_wings
6483 4 0 0.50
6484 2 2 0.25
6485 6 0 0.25
6486 dtype: float64
6487  
6488 With `dropna` set to `False` we can also count rows with NA values.
6489  
6490 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'first_name': ['John', 'Anne', 'John', 'Beth'],
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
6491 ... 'middle_name': ['Smith', pd.NA, pd.NA, 'Louise']})
6492 >>> df
6493 first_name middle_name
6494 0 John Smith
6495 1 Anne <NA>
6496 2 John <NA>
6497 3 Beth Louise
6498  
6499 >>> df.value_counts()
6500 first_name middle_name
6501 Beth Louise 1
6502 John Smith 1
6503 dtype: int64
6504  
6505 >>> df.value_counts(dropna=False)
6506 first_name middle_name
6507 Anne NaN 1
6508 Beth Louise 1
6509 John Smith 1
6510 NaN 1
6511 dtype: int64
6512 """
6513 if subset is None:
6514 subset = self.columns.tolist()
6515  
6516 counts = self.groupby(subset, dropna=dropna).grouper.size()
6517  
6518 if sort:
6519 counts = counts.sort_values(ascending=ascending)
6520 if normalize:
6521 counts /= counts.sum()
6522  
6523 # Force MultiIndex for single column
6524 if len(subset) == 1:
6525 counts.index = MultiIndex.from_arrays(
6526 [counts.index], names=[counts.index.name]
6527 )
6528  
6529 return counts
6530  
6531 def nlargest(self, n, columns, keep: str = "first") -> DataFrame:
6532 """
6533 Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in descending order.
6534  
6535 Return the first `n` rows with the largest values in `columns`, in
6536 descending order. The columns that are not specified are returned as
6537 well, but not used for ordering.
6538  
6539 This method is equivalent to
6540 ``df.sort_values(columns, ascending=False).head(n)``, but more
6541 performant.
6542  
6543 Parameters
6544 ----------
6545 n : int
6546 Number of rows to return.
6547 columns : label or list of labels
6548 Column label(s) to order by.
6549 keep : {'first', 'last', 'all'}, default 'first'
6550 Where there are duplicate values:
6551  
6552 - `first` : prioritize the first occurrence(s)
6553 - `last` : prioritize the last occurrence(s)
6554 - ``all`` : do not drop any duplicates, even it means
6555 selecting more than `n` items.
6556  
6557 Returns
6558 -------
6559 DataFrame
6560 The first `n` rows ordered by the given columns in descending
6561 order.
6562  
6563 See Also
6564 --------
6565 DataFrame.nsmallest : Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in
6566 ascending order.
6567 DataFrame.sort_values : Sort DataFrame by the values.
6568 DataFrame.head : Return the first `n` rows without re-ordering.
6569  
6570 Notes
6571 -----
6572 This function cannot be used with all column types. For example, when
6573 specifying columns with `object` or `category` dtypes, ``TypeError`` is
6574 raised.
6575  
6576 Examples
6577 --------
6578 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'population': [59000000, 65000000, 434000,
6579 ... 434000, 434000, 337000, 11300,
6580 ... 11300, 11300],
6581 ... 'GDP': [1937894, 2583560 , 12011, 4520, 12128,
6582 ... 17036, 182, 38, 311],
6583 ... 'alpha-2': ["IT", "FR", "MT", "MV", "BN",
6584 ... "IS", "NR", "TV", "AI"]},
6585 ... index=["Italy", "France", "Malta",
6586 ... "Maldives", "Brunei", "Iceland",
6587 ... "Nauru", "Tuvalu", "Anguilla"])
6588 >>> df
6589 population GDP alpha-2
6590 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
6591 France 65000000 2583560 FR
6592 Malta 434000 12011 MT
6593 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
6594 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
6595 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
6596 Nauru 11300 182 NR
6597 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
6598 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
6599  
6600 In the following example, we will use ``nlargest`` to select the three
6601 rows having the largest values in column "population".
6602  
6603 >>> df.nlargest(3, 'population')
6604 population GDP alpha-2
6605 France 65000000 2583560 FR
6606 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
6607 Malta 434000 12011 MT
6608  
6609 When using ``keep='last'``, ties are resolved in reverse order:
6610  
6611 >>> df.nlargest(3, 'population', keep='last')
6612 population GDP alpha-2
6613 France 65000000 2583560 FR
6614 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
6615 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
6616  
6617 When using ``keep='all'``, all duplicate items are maintained:
6618  
6619 >>> df.nlargest(3, 'population', keep='all')
6620 population GDP alpha-2
6621 France 65000000 2583560 FR
6622 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
6623 Malta 434000 12011 MT
6624 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
6625 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
6626  
6627 To order by the largest values in column "population" and then "GDP",
6628 we can specify multiple columns like in the next example.
6629  
6630 >>> df.nlargest(3, ['population', 'GDP'])
6631 population GDP alpha-2
6632 France 65000000 2583560 FR
6633 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
6634 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
6635 """
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
6636 return algorithms.SelectNFrame(self, n=n, keep=keep, columns=columns).nlargest()
6637  
6638 def nsmallest(self, n, columns, keep: str = "first") -> DataFrame:
6639 """
6640 Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in ascending order.
6641  
6642 Return the first `n` rows with the smallest values in `columns`, in
6643 ascending order. The columns that are not specified are returned as
6644 well, but not used for ordering.
6645  
6646 This method is equivalent to
6647 ``df.sort_values(columns, ascending=True).head(n)``, but more
6648 performant.
6649  
6650 Parameters
6651 ----------
6652 n : int
6653 Number of items to retrieve.
6654 columns : list or str
6655 Column name or names to order by.
6656 keep : {'first', 'last', 'all'}, default 'first'
6657 Where there are duplicate values:
6658  
6659 - ``first`` : take the first occurrence.
6660 - ``last`` : take the last occurrence.
6661 - ``all`` : do not drop any duplicates, even it means
6662 selecting more than `n` items.
6663  
6664 Returns
6665 -------
6666 DataFrame
6667  
6668 See Also
6669 --------
6670 DataFrame.nlargest : Return the first `n` rows ordered by `columns` in
6671 descending order.
6672 DataFrame.sort_values : Sort DataFrame by the values.
6673 DataFrame.head : Return the first `n` rows without re-ordering.
6674  
6675 Examples
6676 --------
6677 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'population': [59000000, 65000000, 434000,
6678 ... 434000, 434000, 337000, 337000,
6679 ... 11300, 11300],
6680 ... 'GDP': [1937894, 2583560 , 12011, 4520, 12128,
6681 ... 17036, 182, 38, 311],
6682 ... 'alpha-2': ["IT", "FR", "MT", "MV", "BN",
6683 ... "IS", "NR", "TV", "AI"]},
6684 ... index=["Italy", "France", "Malta",
6685 ... "Maldives", "Brunei", "Iceland",
6686 ... "Nauru", "Tuvalu", "Anguilla"])
6687 >>> df
6688 population GDP alpha-2
6689 Italy 59000000 1937894 IT
6690 France 65000000 2583560 FR
6691 Malta 434000 12011 MT
6692 Maldives 434000 4520 MV
6693 Brunei 434000 12128 BN
6694 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
6695 Nauru 337000 182 NR
6696 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
6697 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
6698  
6699 In the following example, we will use ``nsmallest`` to select the
6700 three rows having the smallest values in column "population".
6701  
6702 >>> df.nsmallest(3, 'population')
6703 population GDP alpha-2
6704 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
6705 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
6706 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
6707  
6708 When using ``keep='last'``, ties are resolved in reverse order:
6709  
6710 >>> df.nsmallest(3, 'population', keep='last')
6711 population GDP alpha-2
6712 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
6713 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
6714 Nauru 337000 182 NR
6715  
6716 When using ``keep='all'``, all duplicate items are maintained:
6717  
6718 >>> df.nsmallest(3, 'population', keep='all')
6719 population GDP alpha-2
6720 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
6721 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
6722 Iceland 337000 17036 IS
6723 Nauru 337000 182 NR
6724  
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
6725 To order by the smallest values in column "population" and then "GDP", we can
6726 specify multiple columns like in the next example.
6727  
6728 >>> df.nsmallest(3, ['population', 'GDP'])
6729 population GDP alpha-2
6730 Tuvalu 11300 38 TV
6731 Anguilla 11300 311 AI
6732 Nauru 337000 182 NR
6733 """
6734 return algorithms.SelectNFrame(
6735 self, n=n, keep=keep, columns=columns
6736 ).nsmallest()
6737  
6738 @doc(
6739 Series.swaplevel,
6740 klass=_shared_doc_kwargs["klass"],

6742 """axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
6743 The axis to swap levels on. 0 or 'index' for row-wise, 1 or

6746 examples=dedent(
6747 """Examples
6748 --------
6749 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(
6750 ... {"Grade": ["A", "B", "A", "C"]},
6751 ... index=[
6752 ... ["Final exam", "Final exam", "Coursework", "Coursework"],
6753 ... ["History", "Geography", "History", "Geography"],
6754 ... ["January", "February", "March", "April"],
6755 ... ],
6756 ... )
6757 >>> df
6758 Grade
6759 Final exam History January A
6760 Geography February B
6761 Coursework History March A
6762 Geography April C
6763  
6764 In the following example, we will swap the levels of the indices.
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
6765 Here, we will swap the levels column-wise, but levels can be swapped row-wise
6766 in a similar manner. Note that column-wise is the default behaviour.
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
6767 By not supplying any arguments for i and j, we swap the last and second to
6768 last indices.
6769  
6770 >>> df.swaplevel()
6771 Grade
6772 Final exam January History A
6773 February Geography B
6774 Coursework March History A
6775 April Geography C
6776  
6777 By supplying one argument, we can choose which index to swap the last
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
6778 index with. We can for example swap the first index with the last one as
6779 follows.
6780  
6781 >>> df.swaplevel(0)
6782 Grade
6783 January History Final exam A
6784 February Geography Final exam B
6785 March History Coursework A
6786 April Geography Coursework C
6787  
  • E501 Line too long (87 > 79 characters)
6788 We can also define explicitly which indices we want to swap by supplying values
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
6789 for both i and j. Here, we for example swap the first and second indices.
6790  
6791 >>> df.swaplevel(0, 1)
6792 Grade
6793 History Final exam January A
6794 Geography Final exam February B
6795 History Coursework March A
6796 Geography Coursework April C"""
6797 ),

6799 def swaplevel(self, i: Axis = -2, j: Axis = -1, axis: Axis = 0) -> DataFrame:
6800 result = self.copy()
6801  
6802 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
6803  
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
6804 if not isinstance(result._get_axis(axis), MultiIndex): # pragma: no cover
6805 raise TypeError("Can only swap levels on a hierarchical axis.")
6806  
6807 if axis == 0:
6808 assert isinstance(result.index, MultiIndex)
6809 result.index = result.index.swaplevel(i, j)
6810 else:
6811 assert isinstance(result.columns, MultiIndex)
6812 result.columns = result.columns.swaplevel(i, j)
6813 return result
