9323 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
9324 # Statistical methods, etc.
9325  
9326 def corr(
9327 self,
9328 method: str | Callable[[np.ndarray, np.ndarray], float] = "pearson",
9329 min_periods: int = 1,
9330 ) -> DataFrame:
9331 """
9332 Compute pairwise correlation of columns, excluding NA/null values.
9333  
9334 Parameters
9335 ----------
9336 method : {'pearson', 'kendall', 'spearman'} or callable
9337 Method of correlation:
9338  
9339 * pearson : standard correlation coefficient
9340 * kendall : Kendall Tau correlation coefficient
9341 * spearman : Spearman rank correlation
9342 * callable: callable with input two 1d ndarrays
9343 and returning a float. Note that the returned matrix from corr
9344 will have 1 along the diagonals and will be symmetric
9345 regardless of the callable's behavior.
9346 min_periods : int, optional
9347 Minimum number of observations required per pair of columns
9348 to have a valid result. Currently only available for Pearson
9349 and Spearman correlation.
9350  
9351 Returns
9352 -------
9353 DataFrame
9354 Correlation matrix.
9355  
9356 See Also
9357 --------
9358 DataFrame.corrwith : Compute pairwise correlation with another
9359 DataFrame or Series.
9360 Series.corr : Compute the correlation between two Series.
9361  
9362 Examples
9363 --------
9364 >>> def histogram_intersection(a, b):
9365 ... v = np.minimum(a, b).sum().round(decimals=1)
9366 ... return v
9367 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([(.2, .3), (.0, .6), (.6, .0), (.2, .1)],
9368 ... columns=['dogs', 'cats'])
9369 >>> df.corr(method=histogram_intersection)
9370 dogs cats
9371 dogs 1.0 0.3
9372 cats 0.3 1.0
9373 """
9374 numeric_df = self._get_numeric_data()
9375 cols = numeric_df.columns
9376 idx = cols.copy()
9377 mat = numeric_df.to_numpy(dtype=float, na_value=np.nan, copy=False)
9378  
9379 if method == "pearson":
9380 correl = libalgos.nancorr(mat, minp=min_periods)
9381 elif method == "spearman":
9382 correl = libalgos.nancorr_spearman(mat, minp=min_periods)
9383 elif method == "kendall" or callable(method):
9384 if min_periods is None:
9385 min_periods = 1
9386 mat = mat.T
9387 corrf = nanops.get_corr_func(method)
9388 K = len(cols)
9389 correl = np.empty((K, K), dtype=float)
9390 mask = np.isfinite(mat)
9391 for i, ac in enumerate(mat):
9392 for j, bc in enumerate(mat):
9393 if i > j:
9394 continue
9395  
9396 valid = mask[i] & mask[j]
9397 if valid.sum() < min_periods:
9398 c = np.nan
9399 elif i == j:
9400 c = 1.0
9401 elif not valid.all():
9402 c = corrf(ac[valid], bc[valid])
9403 else:
9404 c = corrf(ac, bc)
9405 correl[i, j] = c
9406 correl[j, i] = c
9407 else:
9408 raise ValueError(
9409 "method must be either 'pearson', "
9410 "'spearman', 'kendall', or a callable, "
9411 f"'{method}' was supplied"
9412 )
9413  
9414 return self._constructor(correl, index=idx, columns=cols)
9415  
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
9416 def cov(self, min_periods: int | None = None, ddof: int | None = 1) -> DataFrame:
9417 """
9418 Compute pairwise covariance of columns, excluding NA/null values.
9419  
9420 Compute the pairwise covariance among the series of a DataFrame.
9421 The returned data frame is the `covariance matrix
9422 <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covariance_matrix>`__ of the columns
9423 of the DataFrame.
9424  
9425 Both NA and null values are automatically excluded from the
9426 calculation. (See the note below about bias from missing values.)
9427 A threshold can be set for the minimum number of
9428 observations for each value created. Comparisons with observations
9429 below this threshold will be returned as ``NaN``.
9430  
9431 This method is generally used for the analysis of time series data to
9432 understand the relationship between different measures
9433 across time.
9434  
9435 Parameters
9436 ----------
9437 min_periods : int, optional
9438 Minimum number of observations required per pair of columns
9439 to have a valid result.
9440  
9441 ddof : int, default 1
9442 Delta degrees of freedom. The divisor used in calculations
9443 is ``N - ddof``, where ``N`` represents the number of elements.
9444  
9445 .. versionadded:: 1.1.0
9446  
9447 Returns
9448 -------
9449 DataFrame
9450 The covariance matrix of the series of the DataFrame.
9451  
9452 See Also
9453 --------
9454 Series.cov : Compute covariance with another Series.
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
9455 core.window.ExponentialMovingWindow.cov: Exponential weighted sample covariance.
9456 core.window.Expanding.cov : Expanding sample covariance.
9457 core.window.Rolling.cov : Rolling sample covariance.
9458  
9459 Notes
9460 -----
9461 Returns the covariance matrix of the DataFrame's time series.
9462 The covariance is normalized by N-ddof.
9463  
9464 For DataFrames that have Series that are missing data (assuming that
9465 data is `missing at random
9466 <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missing_data#Missing_at_random>`__)
9467 the returned covariance matrix will be an unbiased estimate
9468 of the variance and covariance between the member Series.
9469  
9470 However, for many applications this estimate may not be acceptable
9471 because the estimate covariance matrix is not guaranteed to be positive
9472 semi-definite. This could lead to estimate correlations having
9473 absolute values which are greater than one, and/or a non-invertible
9474 covariance matrix. See `Estimation of covariance matrices
9475 <https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Estimation_of_covariance_
9476 matrices>`__ for more details.
9477  
9478 Examples
9479 --------
9480 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([(1, 2), (0, 3), (2, 0), (1, 1)],
9481 ... columns=['dogs', 'cats'])
9482 >>> df.cov()
9483 dogs cats
9484 dogs 0.666667 -1.000000
9485 cats -1.000000 1.666667
9486  
9487 >>> np.random.seed(42)
9488 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(1000, 5),
9489 ... columns=['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'])
9490 >>> df.cov()
9491 a b c d e
9492 a 0.998438 -0.020161 0.059277 -0.008943 0.014144
9493 b -0.020161 1.059352 -0.008543 -0.024738 0.009826
9494 c 0.059277 -0.008543 1.010670 -0.001486 -0.000271
9495 d -0.008943 -0.024738 -0.001486 0.921297 -0.013692
9496 e 0.014144 0.009826 -0.000271 -0.013692 0.977795
9497  
9498 **Minimum number of periods**
9499  
9500 This method also supports an optional ``min_periods`` keyword
9501 that specifies the required minimum number of non-NA observations for
9502 each column pair in order to have a valid result:
9503  
9504 >>> np.random.seed(42)
9505 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(20, 3),
9506 ... columns=['a', 'b', 'c'])
9507 >>> df.loc[df.index[:5], 'a'] = np.nan
9508 >>> df.loc[df.index[5:10], 'b'] = np.nan
9509 >>> df.cov(min_periods=12)
9510 a b c
9511 a 0.316741 NaN -0.150812
9512 b NaN 1.248003 0.191417
9513 c -0.150812 0.191417 0.895202
9514 """
9515 numeric_df = self._get_numeric_data()
9516 cols = numeric_df.columns
9517 idx = cols.copy()
9518 mat = numeric_df.to_numpy(dtype=float, na_value=np.nan, copy=False)
9519  
9520 if notna(mat).all():
9521 if min_periods is not None and min_periods > len(mat):
9522 base_cov = np.empty((mat.shape[1], mat.shape[1]))
9523 base_cov.fill(np.nan)
9524 else:
9525 base_cov = np.cov(mat.T, ddof=ddof)
9526 base_cov = base_cov.reshape((len(cols), len(cols)))
9527 else:
9528 base_cov = libalgos.nancorr(mat, cov=True, minp=min_periods)
9529  
9530 return self._constructor(base_cov, index=idx, columns=cols)
9531  
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
9532 def corrwith(self, other, axis: Axis = 0, drop=False, method="pearson") -> Series:
9533 """
9534 Compute pairwise correlation.
9535  
9536 Pairwise correlation is computed between rows or columns of
9537 DataFrame with rows or columns of Series or DataFrame. DataFrames
9538 are first aligned along both axes before computing the
9539 correlations.
9540  
9541 Parameters
9542 ----------
9543 other : DataFrame, Series
9544 Object with which to compute correlations.
9545 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
9546 The axis to use. 0 or 'index' to compute column-wise, 1 or 'columns' for
9547 row-wise.
9548 drop : bool, default False
9549 Drop missing indices from result.
9550 method : {'pearson', 'kendall', 'spearman'} or callable
9551 Method of correlation:
9552  
9553 * pearson : standard correlation coefficient
9554 * kendall : Kendall Tau correlation coefficient
9555 * spearman : Spearman rank correlation
9556 * callable: callable with input two 1d ndarrays
9557 and returning a float.
9558  
9559 Returns
9560 -------
9561 Series
9562 Pairwise correlations.
9563  
9564 See Also
9565 --------
9566 DataFrame.corr : Compute pairwise correlation of columns.
9567 """
9568 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
9569 this = self._get_numeric_data()
9570  
9571 if isinstance(other, Series):
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
9572 return this.apply(lambda x: other.corr(x, method=method), axis=axis)
9573  
9574 other = other._get_numeric_data()
9575 left, right = this.align(other, join="inner", copy=False)
9576  
9577 if axis == 1:
9578 left = left.T
9579 right = right.T
9580  
9581 if method == "pearson":
9582 # mask missing values
9583 left = left + right * 0
9584 right = right + left * 0
9585  
9586 # demeaned data
9587 ldem = left - left.mean()
9588 rdem = right - right.mean()
9589  
9590 num = (ldem * rdem).sum()
9591 dom = (left.count() - 1) * left.std() * right.std()
9592  
9593 correl = num / dom
9594  
9595 elif method in ["kendall", "spearman"] or callable(method):
9596  
9597 def c(x):
9598 return nanops.nancorr(x[0], x[1], method=method)
9599  
9600 correl = self._constructor_sliced(
9601 map(c, zip(left.values.T, right.values.T)), index=left.columns
9602 )
9603  
9604 else:
9605 raise ValueError(
9606 f"Invalid method {method} was passed, "
9607 "valid methods are: 'pearson', 'kendall', "
9608 "'spearman', or callable"
9609 )
9610  
9611 if not drop:
9612 # Find non-matching labels along the given axis
9613 # and append missing correlations (GH 22375)
9614 raxis = 1 if axis == 0 else 0
9615 result_index = this._get_axis(raxis).union(other._get_axis(raxis))
9616 idx_diff = result_index.difference(correl.index)
9617  
9618 if len(idx_diff) > 0:
  • E501 Line too long (88 > 79 characters)
9619 correl = correl.append(Series([np.nan] * len(idx_diff), index=idx_diff))
9620  
9621 return correl

9626 def count(

9627 self, axis: Axis = 0, level: Level | None = None, numeric_only: bool = False
9628 ):
9629 """
9630 Count non-NA cells for each column or row.
9631  
9632 The values `None`, `NaN`, `NaT`, and optionally `numpy.inf` (depending
9633 on `pandas.options.mode.use_inf_as_na`) are considered NA.
9634  
9635 Parameters
9636 ----------
9637 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
9638 If 0 or 'index' counts are generated for each column.
9639 If 1 or 'columns' counts are generated for each row.
9640 level : int or str, optional
9641 If the axis is a `MultiIndex` (hierarchical), count along a
9642 particular `level`, collapsing into a `DataFrame`.
9643 A `str` specifies the level name.
9644 numeric_only : bool, default False
9645 Include only `float`, `int` or `boolean` data.
9646  
9647 Returns
9648 -------
9649 Series or DataFrame
9650 For each column/row the number of non-NA/null entries.
9651 If `level` is specified returns a `DataFrame`.
9652  
9653 See Also
9654 --------
9655 Series.count: Number of non-NA elements in a Series.
9656 DataFrame.value_counts: Count unique combinations of columns.
9657 DataFrame.shape: Number of DataFrame rows and columns (including NA
9658 elements).
9659 DataFrame.isna: Boolean same-sized DataFrame showing places of NA
9660 elements.
9661  
9662 Examples
9663 --------
9664 Constructing DataFrame from a dictionary:
9665  
9666 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({"Person":
9667 ... ["John", "Myla", "Lewis", "John", "Myla"],
9668 ... "Age": [24., np.nan, 21., 33, 26],
9669 ... "Single": [False, True, True, True, False]})
9670 >>> df
9671 Person Age Single
9672 0 John 24.0 False
9673 1 Myla NaN True
9674 2 Lewis 21.0 True
9675 3 John 33.0 True
9676 4 Myla 26.0 False
9677  
9678 Notice the uncounted NA values:
9679  
9680 >>> df.count()
9681 Person 5
9682 Age 4
9683 Single 5
9684 dtype: int64
9685  
9686 Counts for each **row**:
9687

9689 0 3
9690 1 2
9691 2 3
9692 3 3
9693 4 3
9694 dtype: int64
9695 """

9698 warnings.warn(

9704 )

9730 def _count_level(self, level: Level, axis: int = 0, numeric_only: bool = False):

9733 else:
9734 frame = self

9738

9740 raise TypeError(
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
9741 f"Can only count levels on hierarchical {self._get_axis_name(axis)}."

9745 # values in the DataFrame that are NaN

9748 # upcast everything to object

9752 values_mask = notna(frame.values)
9753

9774  
9775 def _reduce(
9776 self,
9777 op,
9778 name: str,
9779 *,
9780 axis: Axis = 0,
9781 skipna: bool = True,
9782 numeric_only: bool | None = None,
9783 filter_type=None,
9784 **kwds,
9785 ):
9786  
9787 assert filter_type is None or filter_type == "bool", filter_type
9788 out_dtype = "bool" if filter_type == "bool" else None
9789  
9790 own_dtypes = [arr.dtype for arr in self._iter_column_arrays()]
9791  
9792 dtype_is_dt = np.array(
9793 [is_datetime64_any_dtype(dtype) for dtype in own_dtypes],
9794 dtype=bool,
9795 )
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
9796 if numeric_only is None and name in ["mean", "median"] and dtype_is_dt.any():
9797 warnings.warn(
9798 "DataFrame.mean and DataFrame.median with numeric_only=None "
9799 "will include datetime64 and datetime64tz columns in a "
9800 "future version.",
9801 FutureWarning,
9802 stacklevel=5,
9803 )
9804 cols = self.columns[~dtype_is_dt]
9805 self = self[cols]
9806  
9807 # TODO: Make other agg func handle axis=None properly GH#21597
9808 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
9809 labels = self._get_agg_axis(axis)
9810 assert axis in [0, 1]
9811  
9812 def func(values: np.ndarray):
9813 # We only use this in the case that operates on self.values
9814 return op(values, axis=axis, skipna=skipna, **kwds)
9815  
9816 def blk_func(values, axis=1):
9817 if isinstance(values, ExtensionArray):
9818 if not is_1d_only_ea_obj(values) and not isinstance(
9819 self._mgr, ArrayManager
9820 ):
9821 return values._reduce(name, axis=1, skipna=skipna, **kwds)
9822 return values._reduce(name, skipna=skipna, **kwds)
9823 else:
9824 return op(values, axis=axis, skipna=skipna, **kwds)
9825  
9826 def _get_data() -> DataFrame:
9827 if filter_type is None:
9828 data = self._get_numeric_data()
9829 else:
9830 # GH#25101, GH#24434
9831 assert filter_type == "bool"
9832 data = self._get_bool_data()
9833 return data
9834  
9835 if numeric_only is not None or axis == 0:
9836 # For numeric_only non-None and axis non-None, we know
9837 # which blocks to use and no try/except is needed.
9838 # For numeric_only=None only the case with axis==0 and no object
9839 # dtypes are unambiguous can be handled with BlockManager.reduce
9840 # Case with EAs see GH#35881
9841 df = self
9842 if numeric_only is True:
9843 df = _get_data()
9844 if axis == 1:
9845 df = df.T
9846 axis = 0
9847  
9848 ignore_failures = numeric_only is None
9849  
9850 # After possibly _get_data and transposing, we are now in the
9851 # simple case where we can use BlockManager.reduce
9852 res, _ = df._mgr.reduce(blk_func, ignore_failures=ignore_failures)
9853 out = df._constructor(res).iloc[0]
9854 if out_dtype is not None:
9855 out = out.astype(out_dtype)
9856 if axis == 0 and len(self) == 0 and name in ["sum", "prod"]:
9857 # Even if we are object dtype, follow numpy and return
9858 # float64, see test_apply_funcs_over_empty
9859 out = out.astype(np.float64)
9860  
9861 if numeric_only is None and out.shape[0] != df.shape[1]:
9862 # columns have been dropped GH#41480
9863 arg_name = "numeric_only"
9864 if name in ["all", "any"]:
9865 arg_name = "bool_only"
9866 warnings.warn(
9867 "Dropping of nuisance columns in DataFrame reductions "
9868 f"(with '{arg_name}=None') is deprecated; in a future "
9869 "version this will raise TypeError. Select only valid "
9870 "columns before calling the reduction.",
9871 FutureWarning,
9872 stacklevel=5,
9873 )
9874  
9875 return out
9876  
9877 assert numeric_only is None
9878  
9879 data = self
9880 values = data.values
9881  
9882 try:
9883 result = func(values)
9884  
9885 except TypeError:
9886 # e.g. in nanops trying to convert strs to float
9887  
9888 data = _get_data()
9889 labels = data._get_agg_axis(axis)
9890  
9891 values = data.values
9892 with np.errstate(all="ignore"):
9893 result = func(values)
9894  
9895 # columns have been dropped GH#41480
9896 arg_name = "numeric_only"
9897 if name in ["all", "any"]:
9898 arg_name = "bool_only"
9899 warnings.warn(
9900 "Dropping of nuisance columns in DataFrame reductions "
9901 f"(with '{arg_name}=None') is deprecated; in a future "
9902 "version this will raise TypeError. Select only valid "
9903 "columns before calling the reduction.",
9904 FutureWarning,
9905 stacklevel=5,
9906 )
9907  
9908 if hasattr(result, "dtype"):
9909 if filter_type == "bool" and notna(result).all():
9910 result = result.astype(np.bool_)
9911 elif filter_type is None and is_object_dtype(result.dtype):
9912 try:
9913 result = result.astype(np.float64)
9914 except (ValueError, TypeError):
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
9915 # try to coerce to the original dtypes item by item if we can
9916 pass
9917  
9918 result = self._constructor_sliced(result, index=labels)
9919 return result
9920  
9921 def nunique(self, axis: Axis = 0, dropna: bool = True) -> Series:
9922 """
9923 Count number of distinct elements in specified axis.
9924  
9925 Return Series with number of distinct elements. Can ignore NaN
9926 values.
9927  
9928 Parameters
9929 ----------
9930 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
9931 The axis to use. 0 or 'index' for row-wise, 1 or 'columns' for
9932 column-wise.
9933 dropna : bool, default True
9934 Don't include NaN in the counts.
9935  
9936 Returns
9937 -------
9938 Series
9939  
9940 See Also
9941 --------
9942 Series.nunique: Method nunique for Series.
9943 DataFrame.count: Count non-NA cells for each column or row.
9944  
9945 Examples
9946 --------
9947 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [4, 5, 6], 'B': [4, 1, 1]})
9948 >>> df.nunique()
9949 A 3
9950 B 2
9951 dtype: int64
9952  
9953 >>> df.nunique(axis=1)
9954 0 1
9955 1 2
9956 2 2
9957 dtype: int64
9958 """
9959 return self.apply(Series.nunique, axis=axis, dropna=dropna)
9960  
9961 def idxmin(self, axis: Axis = 0, skipna: bool = True) -> Series:
9962 """
9963 Return index of first occurrence of minimum over requested axis.
9964  
9965 NA/null values are excluded.
9966  
9967 Parameters
9968 ----------
9969 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
  • E501 Line too long (87 > 79 characters)
9970 The axis to use. 0 or 'index' for row-wise, 1 or 'columns' for column-wise.
9971 skipna : bool, default True
9972 Exclude NA/null values. If an entire row/column is NA, the result
9973 will be NA.
9974  
9975 Returns
9976 -------
9977 Series
9978 Indexes of minima along the specified axis.
9979  
9980 Raises
9981 ------
9982 ValueError
9983 * If the row/column is empty

9987 Series.idxmin : Return index of the minimum element.
9988  
9989 Notes
9990 -----
9991 This method is the DataFrame version of ``ndarray.argmin``.
9992  
9993 Examples
9994 --------
9995 Consider a dataset containing food consumption in Argentina.
9996  
9997 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'consumption': [10.51, 103.11, 55.48],
9998 ... 'co2_emissions': [37.2, 19.66, 1712]},
9999 ... index=['Pork', 'Wheat Products', 'Beef'])
10000  
10001 >>> df
10002 consumption co2_emissions
10003 Pork 10.51 37.20
10004 Wheat Products 103.11 19.66
10005 Beef 55.48 1712.00
10006  
10007 By default, it returns the index for the minimum value in each column.
10008  
10009 >>> df.idxmin()
10010 consumption Pork
10011 co2_emissions Wheat Products
10012 dtype: object
10013  
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
10014 To return the index for the minimum value in each row, use ``axis="columns"``.
10015  
10016 >>> df.idxmin(axis="columns")
10017 Pork consumption
10018 Wheat Products co2_emissions
10019 Beef consumption
10020 dtype: object
10021 """

10023  
10024 res = self._reduce(
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)

10026 )
10027 indices = res._values
10028  
10029 # indices will always be np.ndarray since axis is not None and
10030 # values is a 2d array for DataFrame
10031 # error: Item "int" of "Union[int, Any]" has no attribute "__iter__"
10032 assert isinstance(indices, np.ndarray) # for mypy
10033  
10034 index = self._get_axis(axis)
10035 result = [index[i] if i >= 0 else np.nan for i in indices]
10036 return self._constructor_sliced(result, index=self._get_agg_axis(axis))

10114  
10115 def _get_agg_axis(self, axis_num: int) -> Index:
10116 """
10117 Let's be explicit about this.
10118 """
10119 if axis_num == 0:
10120 return self.columns
10121 elif axis_num == 1:
10122 return self.index
10123 else:
10124 raise ValueError(f"Axis must be 0 or 1 (got {repr(axis_num)})")
10125  
10126 def mode(
10127 self, axis: Axis = 0, numeric_only: bool = False, dropna: bool = True
10128 ) -> DataFrame:
10129 """
10130 Get the mode(s) of each element along the selected axis.
10131  
10132 The mode of a set of values is the value that appears most often.
10133 It can be multiple values.
10134  
10135 Parameters
10136 ----------
10137 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
10138 The axis to iterate over while searching for the mode:
10139  
10140 * 0 or 'index' : get mode of each column
10141 * 1 or 'columns' : get mode of each row.
10142  
10143 numeric_only : bool, default False
10144 If True, only apply to numeric columns.
10145 dropna : bool, default True
10146 Don't consider counts of NaN/NaT.
10147  
10148 Returns
10149 -------
10150 DataFrame
10151 The modes of each column or row.
10152  
10153 See Also
10154 --------
10155 Series.mode : Return the highest frequency value in a Series.
10156 Series.value_counts : Return the counts of values in a Series.
10157  
10158 Examples
10159 --------
10160 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([('bird', 2, 2),
10161 ... ('mammal', 4, np.nan),
10162 ... ('arthropod', 8, 0),
10163 ... ('bird', 2, np.nan)],
10164 ... index=('falcon', 'horse', 'spider', 'ostrich'),
10165 ... columns=('species', 'legs', 'wings'))
10166 >>> df
10167 species legs wings
10168 falcon bird 2 2.0
10169 horse mammal 4 NaN
10170 spider arthropod 8 0.0
10171 ostrich bird 2 NaN
10172  
10173 By default, missing values are not considered, and the mode of wings
10174 are both 0 and 2. Because the resulting DataFrame has two rows,
10175 the second row of ``species`` and ``legs`` contains ``NaN``.
10176  
10177 >>> df.mode()
10178 species legs wings
10179 0 bird 2.0 0.0
10180 1 NaN NaN 2.0
10181  
10182 Setting ``dropna=False`` ``NaN`` values are considered and they can be
10183 the mode (like for wings).
10184  
10185 >>> df.mode(dropna=False)
10186 species legs wings
10187 0 bird 2 NaN
10188  
10189 Setting ``numeric_only=True``, only the mode of numeric columns is
10190 computed, and columns of other types are ignored.
10191  
10192 >>> df.mode(numeric_only=True)
10193 legs wings
10194 0 2.0 0.0
10195 1 NaN 2.0
10196  
10197 To compute the mode over columns and not rows, use the axis parameter:
10198  
10199 >>> df.mode(axis='columns', numeric_only=True)
10200 0 1
10201 falcon 2.0 NaN
10202 horse 4.0 NaN
10203 spider 0.0 8.0
10204 ostrich 2.0 NaN
10205 """
10206 data = self if not numeric_only else self._get_numeric_data()
10207  
10208 def f(s):
10209 return s.mode(dropna=dropna)
10210  
10211 data = data.apply(f, axis=axis)
10212 # Ensure index is type stable (should always use int index)
10213 if data.empty:
10214 data.index = ibase.default_index(0)
10215  
10216 return data
10217  
10218 def quantile(
10219 self,
10220 q=0.5,
10221 axis: Axis = 0,
10222 numeric_only: bool = True,
10223 interpolation: str = "linear",
10224 ):
10225 """
10226 Return values at the given quantile over requested axis.
10227  
10228 Parameters
10229 ----------
10230 q : float or array-like, default 0.5 (50% quantile)
10231 Value between 0 <= q <= 1, the quantile(s) to compute.
10232 axis : {0, 1, 'index', 'columns'}, default 0
10233 Equals 0 or 'index' for row-wise, 1 or 'columns' for column-wise.
10234 numeric_only : bool, default True
10235 If False, the quantile of datetime and timedelta data will be
10236 computed as well.
10237 interpolation : {'linear', 'lower', 'higher', 'midpoint', 'nearest'}
10238 This optional parameter specifies the interpolation method to use,
10239 when the desired quantile lies between two data points `i` and `j`:
10240  
10241 * linear: `i + (j - i) * fraction`, where `fraction` is the
10242 fractional part of the index surrounded by `i` and `j`.
10243 * lower: `i`.
10244 * higher: `j`.
10245 * nearest: `i` or `j` whichever is nearest.
10246 * midpoint: (`i` + `j`) / 2.
10247  
10248 Returns
10249 -------
10250 Series or DataFrame
10251  
10252 If ``q`` is an array, a DataFrame will be returned where the
10253 index is ``q``, the columns are the columns of self, and the
10254 values are the quantiles.
10255 If ``q`` is a float, a Series will be returned where the
10256 index is the columns of self and the values are the quantiles.
10257  
10258 See Also
10259 --------
10260 core.window.Rolling.quantile: Rolling quantile.
10261 numpy.percentile: Numpy function to compute the percentile.
10262  
10263 Examples
10264 --------
10265 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(np.array([[1, 1], [2, 10], [3, 100], [4, 100]]),
10266 ... columns=['a', 'b'])
10267 >>> df.quantile(.1)
10268 a 1.3
10269 b 3.7
10270 Name: 0.1, dtype: float64
10271 >>> df.quantile([.1, .5])
10272 a b
10273 0.1 1.3 3.7
10274 0.5 2.5 55.0
10275  
10276 Specifying `numeric_only=False` will also compute the quantile of
10277 datetime and timedelta data.
10278  
10279 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2],
10280 ... 'B': [pd.Timestamp('2010'),
10281 ... pd.Timestamp('2011')],
10282 ... 'C': [pd.Timedelta('1 days'),
10283 ... pd.Timedelta('2 days')]})
10284 >>> df.quantile(0.5, numeric_only=False)
10285 A 1.5
10286 B 2010-07-02 12:00:00
10287 C 1 days 12:00:00
10288 Name: 0.5, dtype: object
10289 """
10290 validate_percentile(q)
10291  
10292 if not is_list_like(q):
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
10293 # BlockManager.quantile expects listlike, so we wrap and unwrap here
10294 res = self.quantile(
  • E501 Line too long (86 > 79 characters)
10295 [q], axis=axis, numeric_only=numeric_only, interpolation=interpolation
10296 )
10297 return res.iloc[0]
10298  
10299 q = Index(q, dtype=np.float64)
10300 data = self._get_numeric_data() if numeric_only else self
10301 axis = self._get_axis_number(axis)
10302  
10303 if axis == 1:
10304 data = data.T
10305  
10306 if len(data.columns) == 0:
10307 # GH#23925 _get_numeric_data may have dropped all columns
10308 cols = Index([], name=self.columns.name)
10309 if is_list_like(q):
10310 return self._constructor([], index=q, columns=cols)
  • E501 Line too long (85 > 79 characters)
10311 return self._constructor_sliced([], index=cols, name=q, dtype=np.float64)
10312  
10313 res = data._mgr.quantile(qs=q, axis=1, interpolation=interpolation)
10314  
10315 result = self._constructor(res)
10316 return result

10366 def to_timestamp(
10367 self,
10368 freq: Frequency | None = None,
10369 how: str = "start",
10370 axis: Axis = 0,
10371 copy: bool = True,
10372 ) -> DataFrame:
10373 """
10374 Cast to DatetimeIndex of timestamps, at *beginning* of period.
10375  
10376 Parameters
10377 ----------
10378 freq : str, default frequency of PeriodIndex
10379 Desired frequency.
10380 how : {'s', 'e', 'start', 'end'}
10381 Convention for converting period to timestamp; start of period
10382 vs. end.
10383 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
10384 The axis to convert (the index by default).
10385 copy : bool, default True
10386 If False then underlying input data is not copied.
10387  
10388 Returns
10389 -------
10390 DataFrame with DatetimeIndex
10391 """
10392 new_obj = self.copy(deep=copy)
10393  
10394 axis_name = self._get_axis_name(axis)
10395 old_ax = getattr(self, axis_name)
10396 if not isinstance(old_ax, PeriodIndex):
10397 raise TypeError(f"unsupported Type {type(old_ax).__name__}")
10398  
10399 new_ax = old_ax.to_timestamp(freq=freq, how=how)
10400  
10401 setattr(new_obj, axis_name, new_ax)
10402 return new_obj
10403  
10404 def to_period(
10405 self, freq: Frequency | None = None, axis: Axis = 0, copy: bool = True
10406 ) -> DataFrame:
10407 """
10408 Convert DataFrame from DatetimeIndex to PeriodIndex.
10409  
10410 Convert DataFrame from DatetimeIndex to PeriodIndex with desired
10411 frequency (inferred from index if not passed).
10412  
10413 Parameters
10414 ----------
10415 freq : str, default
10416 Frequency of the PeriodIndex.
10417 axis : {0 or 'index', 1 or 'columns'}, default 0
10418 The axis to convert (the index by default).
10419 copy : bool, default True
10420 If False then underlying input data is not copied.
10421  
10422 Returns
10423 -------
10424 DataFrame with PeriodIndex
10425 """
10426 new_obj = self.copy(deep=copy)
10427  
10428 axis_name = self._get_axis_name(axis)
10429 old_ax = getattr(self, axis_name)
10430 if not isinstance(old_ax, DatetimeIndex):
10431 raise TypeError(f"unsupported Type {type(old_ax).__name__}")
10432  
10433 new_ax = old_ax.to_period(freq=freq)
10434  
10435 setattr(new_obj, axis_name, new_ax)
10436 return new_obj
10437  
10438 def isin(self, values) -> DataFrame:
10439 """
10440 Whether each element in the DataFrame is contained in values.
10441  
10442 Parameters
10443 ----------
10444 values : iterable, Series, DataFrame or dict
10445 The result will only be true at a location if all the
10446 labels match. If `values` is a Series, that's the index. If
10447 `values` is a dict, the keys must be the column names,
10448 which must match. If `values` is a DataFrame,
10449 then both the index and column labels must match.
10450  
10451 Returns
10452 -------
10453 DataFrame
10454 DataFrame of booleans showing whether each element in the DataFrame
10455 is contained in values.
10456  
10457 See Also
10458 --------
10459 DataFrame.eq: Equality test for DataFrame.
10460 Series.isin: Equivalent method on Series.
10461 Series.str.contains: Test if pattern or regex is contained within a
10462 string of a Series or Index.
10463  
10464 Examples
10465 --------
10466 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'num_legs': [2, 4], 'num_wings': [2, 0]},
10467 ... index=['falcon', 'dog'])
10468 >>> df
10469 num_legs num_wings
10470 falcon 2 2
10471 dog 4 0
10472  
10473 When ``values`` is a list check whether every value in the DataFrame
10474 is present in the list (which animals have 0 or 2 legs or wings)
10475  
10476 >>> df.isin([0, 2])
10477 num_legs num_wings
10478 falcon True True
10479 dog False True
10480  
10481 When ``values`` is a dict, we can pass values to check for each
10482 column separately:
10483  
10484 >>> df.isin({'num_wings': [0, 3]})
10485 num_legs num_wings
10486 falcon False False
10487 dog False True
10488  
10489 When ``values`` is a Series or DataFrame the index and column must
10490 match. Note that 'falcon' does not match based on the number of legs
10491 in df2.
10492  
10493 >>> other = pd.DataFrame({'num_legs': [8, 2], 'num_wings': [0, 2]},
10494 ... index=['spider', 'falcon'])
10495 >>> df.isin(other)
10496 num_legs num_wings
10497 falcon True True
10498 dog False False
10499 """
10500 if isinstance(values, dict):
10501 from pandas.core.reshape.concat import concat
10502  
10503 values = collections.defaultdict(list, values)
10504 return concat(
10505 (
10506 self.iloc[:, [i]].isin(values[col])
10507 for i, col in enumerate(self.columns)
10508 ),
10509 axis=1,
10510 )
10511 elif isinstance(values, Series):
10512 if not values.index.is_unique:
10513 raise ValueError("cannot compute isin with a duplicate axis.")
10514 return self.eq(values.reindex_like(self), axis="index")
10515 elif isinstance(values, DataFrame):
10516 if not (values.columns.is_unique and values.index.is_unique):
10517 raise ValueError("cannot compute isin with a duplicate axis.")
10518 return self.eq(values.reindex_like(self))
10519 else:
10520 if not is_list_like(values):
10521 raise TypeError(
10522 "only list-like or dict-like objects are allowed "
10523 "to be passed to DataFrame.isin(), "
10524 f"you passed a '{type(values).__name__}'"
10525 )
10526 return self._constructor(
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
10527 algorithms.isin(self.values.ravel(), values).reshape(self.shape),
10528 self.index,
10529 self.columns,
10530 )
10531  
10532 # ----------------------------------------------------------------------
10533 # Add index and columns
10534 _AXIS_ORDERS = ["index", "columns"]
10535 _AXIS_TO_AXIS_NUMBER: dict[Axis, int] = {
10536 **NDFrame._AXIS_TO_AXIS_NUMBER,
10537 1: 1,
10538 "columns": 1,
10539 }
10540 _AXIS_REVERSED = True
10541 _AXIS_LEN = len(_AXIS_ORDERS)
10542 _info_axis_number = 1
10543 _info_axis_name = "columns"
10544  
10545 index: Index = properties.AxisProperty(
10546 axis=1, doc="The index (row labels) of the DataFrame."
10547 )
10548 columns: Index = properties.AxisProperty(
10549 axis=0, doc="The column labels of the DataFrame."
10550 )
10551  
10552 @property

10554 """.. deprecated:: 1.1.0"""
10555 super()._AXIS_NUMBERS
10556 return {"index": 0, "columns": 1}

10573  
10574 def _to_dict_of_blocks(self, copy: bool = True):
10575 """
10576 Return a dict of dtype -> Constructor Types that
10577 each is a homogeneous dtype.
10578  
10579 Internal ONLY - only works for BlockManager
10580 """
10581 mgr = self._mgr
  • E501 Line too long (84 > 79 characters)
10582 # convert to BlockManager if needed -> this way support ArrayManager as well
10583 mgr = mgr_to_mgr(mgr, "block")
10584 mgr = cast(BlockManager, mgr)
10585 return {
10586 k: self._constructor(v).__finalize__(self)
10587 for k, v, in mgr.to_dict(copy=copy).items()
10588 }
10589  
10590 @property
10591 def values(self) -> np.ndarray:
10592 """
10593 Return a Numpy representation of the DataFrame.
10594  
10595 .. warning::
10596  
10597 We recommend using :meth:`DataFrame.to_numpy` instead.
10598  
10599 Only the values in the DataFrame will be returned, the axes labels
10600 will be removed.
10601  
10602 Returns
10603 -------
10604 numpy.ndarray
10605 The values of the DataFrame.
10606  
10607 See Also
10608 --------
10609 DataFrame.to_numpy : Recommended alternative to this method.
10610 DataFrame.index : Retrieve the index labels.
10611 DataFrame.columns : Retrieving the column names.
10612  
10613 Notes
10614 -----
10615 The dtype will be a lower-common-denominator dtype (implicit
10616 upcasting); that is to say if the dtypes (even of numeric types)
10617 are mixed, the one that accommodates all will be chosen. Use this
10618 with care if you are not dealing with the blocks.
10619  
10620 e.g. If the dtypes are float16 and float32, dtype will be upcast to
10621 float32. If dtypes are int32 and uint8, dtype will be upcast to
10622 int32. By :func:`numpy.find_common_type` convention, mixing int64
10623 and uint64 will result in a float64 dtype.
10624  
10625 Examples
10626 --------
10627 A DataFrame where all columns are the same type (e.g., int64) results
10628 in an array of the same type.
10629  
10630 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'age': [ 3, 29],
10631 ... 'height': [94, 170],
10632 ... 'weight': [31, 115]})
10633 >>> df
10634 age height weight
10635 0 3 94 31
10636 1 29 170 115
10637 >>> df.dtypes
10638 age int64
10639 height int64
10640 weight int64
10641 dtype: object
10642 >>> df.values
10643 array([[ 3, 94, 31],
10644 [ 29, 170, 115]])
10645  
10646 A DataFrame with mixed type columns(e.g., str/object, int64, float32)
10647 results in an ndarray of the broadest type that accommodates these
10648 mixed types (e.g., object).
10649  
10650 >>> df2 = pd.DataFrame([('parrot', 24.0, 'second'),
10651 ... ('lion', 80.5, 1),
10652 ... ('monkey', np.nan, None)],
10653 ... columns=('name', 'max_speed', 'rank'))
10654 >>> df2.dtypes
10655 name object
10656 max_speed float64
10657 rank object
10658 dtype: object
10659 >>> df2.values
10660 array([['parrot', 24.0, 'second'],
10661 ['lion', 80.5, 1],
10662 ['monkey', nan, None]], dtype=object)
10663 """
10664 self._consolidate_inplace()
10665 return self._mgr.as_array(transpose=True)
10666

10759  
10760 def _from_nested_dict(data) -> collections.defaultdict:
10761 new_data: collections.defaultdict = collections.defaultdict(dict)
10762 for index, s in data.items():
10763 for col, v in s.items():
10764 new_data[col][index] = v
10765 return new_data
10766  
10767  
10768 def _reindex_for_setitem(value: FrameOrSeriesUnion, index: Index) -> ArrayLike:
10769 # reindex if necessary
10770  
10771 if value.index.equals(index) or not len(index):
10772 return value._values.copy()
10773  
10774 # GH#4107
10775 try:
10776 reindexed_value = value.reindex(index)._values
10777 except ValueError as err:
10778 # raised in MultiIndex.from_tuples, see test_insert_error_msmgs
10779 if not value.index.is_unique:
10780 # duplicate axis
10781 raise err
10782  
10783 raise TypeError(
10784 "incompatible index of inserted column with frame index"
10785 ) from err
10786 return reindexed_value
